Acceptance

text: Which of the following statements is an example of enhancing an opportunity?
explanation: Enhance means increase probability or impact. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 444 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 125

choices.text: By forming a partnership with another company, the project’s value will increase for both companies.
By taking additional actions, you increase the probability of potential profit.
By taking out insurance, you can reduce potential costs to the project.
By documenting the opportunity in the watchlist, you can keep track of it and ensure it gets exploited.

text: You are a project manager for a data center upgrade project. The data center uses old systems and your project was to upgrade to a new system. The project was planned to be in winter were heavy rains are likely to happen. The heavy rains caused power outages just when the project was near completion. When the power was restored, all of the project customer’s data were lost with no way of retrieving them. What should have been done to prevent this problem?
explanation: The risk here is data loss due to power outage. So insurance against this risk will not solve the problem (will not restore lost data). Planning for a reserve fund is a risk acceptance and it will not restore lost data. Scheduling the installation during summer is a risk avoidance and may solve the problem, but it may have a negative impact on project schedule, so it is not the best solution. The best solution is to monitor the weather and have a contingency plan. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Schedule the installation in summer.
Plan for a reserve fund.
Insure against this risk.
Monitor the weather and have a contingency plan.

text: Carlos is the project manager of a system automation project that was scheduled to be completed within six months. During the early stages of the project, he and the stakeholders operated with the belief that the software that the project team is developing will be compatible with the existing hardware. Now after the project team has started developing the software it has become apparent that the software will not work with part of the existing hardware. The incorrect belief of Carlos and the stakeholders about software compatibility is considered as a/an:
explanation: An assumption is a factor in the planning process that is considered to be true, real, or certain, without proof or demonstration. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 415 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 174

choices.text: Assumption
Issue
Risk
Constraint

text: A project manager for a construction project is meeting with the project team when they informed him that the political climate in their country is not stable and a curfew may be applied which will shorten the working hours by 2 hours daily. This may delay the project by one month. They hold a brainstorming session to try to minimize the impact of the curfew but they found no useful way. Which risk response strategy did they use?
explanation: No specific risk response strategy was selected, so the risk was accepted. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Mitigate
Escalate
Transfer
Accept

text: Which of the following is a risk response strategy that can be used for both opportunities and threats?
explanation: Only Acceptance and Escalation are valid risk response strategy for both opportunities and threats. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 442-444 and PMBOK 7th, Page 123-125

choices.text: Mitigation and Transference
Transference and Escalation
Sharing and Acceptance
Acceptance and Escalation

text: Steve is managing a large construction project which is budgeted at $20,000,000 and will be completed in 2 years. The project is on track with no major issues. Recently, the city council has announced for some new regulations related to the construction projects in the city that will take effect within two years. The new regulations will have an effect on the project budget, however there is low probability that the new regulations will take effect before the project delivery date. What should Steve do?
explanation: First things first, he together with the team should identify a risk, add it to the risk register, make needed analysis and plan a response. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Hold a meeting with the project team to discuss this topic.
It is an unknown-unknown, he can address it through management reserve.
Calculate the effect on the project budget and submit a change request to add it as contingency reserve.
Add a risk to the risk register.

text: Preliminary risk responses may be identified and recorded as part of the ______ process and will be reviewed and confirmed as part of the ______ process.
explanation: Preliminary risk responses may be identified and recorded as part of the Identify Risks process and will be reviewed and confirmed as part of the Plan Risk Responses process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411

choices.text: Identify Risks and Plan Risk Responses
Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis and Plan Risk Responses
Identify Risks and Implement Risk Responses
Plan Risk Management and Plan Risk Responses

text: Dennis is managing a large and complex product development project. The project is very risky, however he could use the best practices in risk identification and has succesfully identified most of the project risks with the project team. The project has overall intensive planning. However, during project executing, the project has experienced several risks, which were already identified. Unfortunately, the project failed to achieve its objectives due to these realized risks. What has gone wrong?
explanation: As the project had intensive planning, this means that risks were properly defined, analyzed and responses were planned. The team spend effort in identifying and analyzing risks and developing risk responses, but no action is taken to manage the risk.

choices.text: The qualitative and quantitative risk analysis were inadequate.
There was not enough management reserve to accommodate the unknown risks.
No action has been taken to manage the identified risks.
There was not enough contingency reserve to accommodate the identified risks.

text: You are a project manager for a product development project. You have a tight budget and the project is behind schedule. One of your team members presents a new software that will help automate some of the project work. By using the new software, the project work will be done faster than planned. The new software will cost 10,000$ and it will help you save 45,000$ in total costs, it will also save 45 days from the total project duration. You decide to purchase the new software and change the project management plan accordingly after the approval of CCB. Which risk response strategy is used in this situation?
explanation: In this situation the project manager changed the project management plan to make sure that the opportunity happens. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 444 and PMBOK 7th, Page 125

choices.text: Enhancing
Exploiting
Acceptance
Sharing

text: You are managing a construction project that will cost 2,000,000$ and will last for 14 months. Before finalizing the project management plan, the project sponsor asks you why you scheduled many risk identification meetings throughout the project. He said that risk identification meeting should be scheduled only during project planning and there is no need for all these risk identification meetings throughout the project. How should you answer him?
explanation: Identify risks is an iterative process, because new risks may evolve or become known as the project progresses through its life cycle. The frequency of iteration and participation in each cycle will vary by situation. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 122

choices.text: The sponsor is your boss. You should follow his advice and schedule risk identification meetings during project planning only.
The iterative meetings allow the risk identification participants to identify newly discovered risks throughout the project.
The Identify Risks process occurs during planning process group, so the risk identification meetings should be also scheduled during planning.
The iterative meetings allow the project manager to discuss the risk events which have passed the project and which did not happen.

text: Which of the following events is least likely to be used as a source for identifying threats?
explanation: Daily standup meetings can be used in any project and are a source for identifying potential threats and opportunities. Frequent demonstrations of increments of the product or service, interim designs, or proof of concepts can surface threats and opportunities. Retrospectives and lessons learned meetings can be used to identify threats to performance, project team cohesion, etc., and to seek improvements. Product backlog refinement is mainly used to prioritize items in product backlog. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 127

choices.text: Daily Standups
Demonstrations
Retrospectives
Backlog Refinement

text: Michael is managing a software project which is a part of a program. During risk identification, a team member has identified an opportunity that he will learn a different programming language to perform a part of this project which may be useful for other parts. Michael noticed that this opportunity will be useful for other projects in the program, but it will not be useful in his project. So, he informed the program manager about this opportunity. Which risk response strategy did Michael use in this situation?
explanation: In this situation, Escalate is the correct answer because the project manager agrees that the proposed response would exceed the project manager’s authority. He escalated the opportunity to be managed at the program level. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 444 and PMBOK 7th, Page 125

choices.text: Transfer, because he transferred it to the program manager.
Escalate, because it needs to be managed at the program level.
Accept, because he did nothing towards this opportunity.
Enhance, because by informing program manager probability will increase.

text: Mark is a project manager for a tele-communications project in his organization. Tom is his sponsor and he is working with David, the risk manager in the organization to determine the effectiveness of the risk responses. Tom and David are concerned that some of the risks assigned to Frederick, a project team member to plan for risk responses may not be addresses to the depth they would like. In this scenario, what is the role of Frederick regarding risk management?
explanation: Frederick here is a risk response owner who is responsible to plan a risk response. He is also a team member, but the question asks what is his role regarding risk management. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 426

choices.text: Risk auditor
Risk response owner
Risk team member
Project team member

text: When you add more risks to the risk register, all of the following will happen except:
explanation: As more risks are identified, the more you need for contingency reserve, the less you need to develop workarounds, your project will proceed with few surprises and you will need to develop more risk responses. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: More risk responses will need to be developed.
The need for contingency reserves is minimized.
The need for workarounds is minimized.
Your project will progress with few surprises.

text: A risk owner will be responsible for:
explanation: A risk owner will be responsible for planning an appropriate risk response and for reporting progress on managing the risk, will be allocated to each individual project risk as part of the Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 426

choices.text: Determining the actual probability and impact for individual project risks.
Planning an appropriate risk response and for reporting progress on managing the risk.
Determining the needed contingency reserve for cost or schedule.
Reassessment of current risks and closing of outdated risks.

text: The lowest level of the risk breakdown structure can be used as a/an:
explanation: The risk categories in the lowest level of the risk breakdown structure can be used as a prompt list for individual project risks. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 416

choices.text: Prioritized list of project risks
Individual project risks
Checklist
Prompt list

text: Antony is managing a large product development project. He and his team have finalized the first round of risk identification with project key stakeholders. They identified hundreds of individual project risks, recommended potential risk owners and risk responses. They also identified sources of overall project risk. Where should sources of overall project risk be documented?
explanation: On completion of the Identify Risks process, information in the risk report may include sources of overall project risk, indicating which are the most important drivers of overall project risk exposure. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 418 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 190

choices.text: Risk Report
Risk Register
Risk Management Plan
Risk Breakdown Structure

text: At the beginning of the project a team member asks you, the project manager, when we should identify risks. Which of the following statements best describes your answer?
explanation: When there is any change to any project constraint, you must evaluate the impacts of this change to all project constraints. This means you must know all risks associated with the change. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 122

choices.text: Whenever there is a change to the project.
After the project charter is received and before the WBS is created.
Before the project charter is created.
During the Validate Scope process.

text: Why will you need to update the WBS after you complete the risk response planning with your team?
explanation: Plan Risk Responses process may result in updates to the project management plan components like WBS because of new, modified or omitted work generated by the risk responses, the scope baseline may be updated to reflect those changes. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 447

choices.text: Because of work that was removed during the WBS creation.
Because of new work added by the risk responses.
Because of risks associated with work packages.
Because of risks generated from decomposing work packages to activities.

text: Which of the following best describes an opportunity on a project?
explanation: The quality requirements are hard to achieve, the requirements might need updating later, and an increase in USD consumer price all have negative impacts on the project. They are all threats not opportunities. While a team member will learn more about something, it will be useful in future projects, so it is considered an opportunity. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 397 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 125

choices.text: The quality requirements are hard to achieve.
The requirements might need updating later.
An increase in USD consumer price may occur, which will need $5,000 contingency reserve.
A team member will learn more about microwaves and can use this information on future projects.

text: You are the project manager for an electronic boards manufacturing project. This project is implemented in a country where both temperature and humidity are high. The boards you manufacture have some components that are sensitive to humidity. If the humidity exceeds 70% , it may damage some humidity sensitive components, which may delay the project by two weeks till you purchase other components, and also will cost the project about 2,000$. So, the humidity degree inside the lab which you use to manufacture electronic boards should not exceed 70%. You work with your project team to develop a response to deal with the humidity problem. What is called the 70% humidity degree?
explanation: Triggers are the warning signs that a risk has occurred or about to occur. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 417

choices.text: Risk Event
Threat
Risk Trigger
Issue

text: Which of the following best describes the output of the Identify Risks process?
explanation: A list of prioritized risks is an output of the Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis process. The outputs of the Identify Risks process is a risk report and a risk register containing a list of risks, root causes of risks, a list of potential responses and a list of potential risk owners. So the best answer is an understanding of project risks not just a list of risks or a list of potential risk owners. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 417

choices.text: A list of potential risk owners
A list of risks
An understanding of the project risks
A list of prioritized risks

text: During the Identify Risks process, a project manager and stakeholders used many methods to identify risks and they identified more than 1000 risks. Then they made sure that all the risks were understood and they identified triggers. Later, in the Plan Risk Responses process, the project manager avoided some identified risks and mitigated others. What has he done wrong?
explanation: More people should be involved in the Plan Risk Responses process, those people may have more experience in dealing with risks. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 441

choices.text: The project manager should have involved more people in the Plan Risk Responses process.
He should identify triggers in the Plan Risk Responses process not in the Identify Risks process.
The project manager should have performed a risk audit.
The project manager should have created workarounds.

text: You are a project manager of a high-risk electronics project which has a lot of new technologies. You created a risk management plan, identified 225 risks, and documented them in a risk register and documented sources of overall project risk, together with summary information on identified individual project risks in a risk report. Then, the risks were analyzed and responses were planned. During risk control meetings. It gets obvious to everyone that the documents you created are not helpful. What have you probably done wrong?
explanation: You should involve everyone in identifying risks. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411

choices.text: You didn't perform quantitative risk analysis for the identified risks.
You did the first processes alone.
You did not identify Triggers.
Risk response owners didn't implement the planned responses.

text: During which risk management processes are most of the project risks identified?
explanation: New risks are identified in the Monitor Risks process and Identify Risks process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411 and 454

choices.text: Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis and Monitor Risks
Identify Risks and Monitor Risks
Implement Risk Responses and Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis
Plan risk responses and Identify Risks

text: You have been promoted to a project manager position in an organization which has a history of handling risks badly. The previous projects didn’t follow the risk management procedures in your organization. Your new project is very important and highly visible in your organization. You have been asked by top management to analyze the project risks and prepare response strategies for them as soon as possible. The project’s first milestone is in three weeks. In preparing the risk response plan, input from which of the following is generally least important?
explanation: Team members know the project deliverables, so their inputs are important. Risk management experts in your organization are responsible for preparing templates and historical information from previous projects, so their inputs are important. Key stakeholders have knowledge about technical work in the project, so their inputs are important in determining risk responses. The project sponsor inputs are least important because he doesn't know the detailed work of the project to solve the project problems. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 441

choices.text: Project team members
Risk management experts in your organization
Project sponsor
Key stakeholders

text: Carol is managing an industrial project. She, her team and the project sponsor find that the level of overall project risk is significantly negative and outside the agreed-upon risk thresholds for the project. They tried to reduce the negative effect of uncertainty on the project as a whole and bring the project back within the thresholds, but they couldn't. So they decided to cancel the project. Which risk response strategy did they use?
explanation: Where it is not possible to bring the project back within the thresholds, the project may be canceled. This represents the most extreme degree of risk avoidance and it should be used only if the overall level of threat is, and will remain, unacceptable. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 445 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Escalate
Accept
Avoid
They didn't use any risk response strategy.

text: You are managing an industrial project which had a lower priority in your organization than other running projects. During risk identification sessions, you and your team identified more than 180 risks for your project. You are afraid that evaluating each of these risks quantitatively will cost you a huge amount of time and money, while most of them are not important enough . What should you do next?
explanation: You must evaluate both probability and impact. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 423

choices.text: Identify risk triggers where possible. Analyze only those risks quantitatively for which no trigger could be found.
Use qualitative risk analysis in order to prioritize risks for further action.
Assess the probability of each risk qualitatively and then analyze only those risks with high probability.
Assess the potential impact of each risk qualitatively and then analyze only those risks with high impact.

text: Laura is the project manager of a new construction project. The project is to build a new hospital in a city during the hurricane season. A stakeholder identified a risk that the hurricane might damage the project deliverables and it may have consequences on project schedule and cost. Laura and her team go on planning as if the risk is not likely to occur. What is the risk response strategy used in this situation?
explanation: They did nothing for the risk and even they didn't plan for a contingency reserve, so the risk is passively accepted. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Active Acceptance
Passive Acceptance
Mitigation
Avoidance

text: Sarah is managing a construction project. During risk identification, a team member identified a risk that previous projects were exposed to thefts, some thieves have stolen cement and building material from the work location. The team agrees that it’s unlikely that theives can steal material from working location. Even if thefts occur,the project will not lose a significant amount of material, because they depend on material delivery as per the daily needs. She decides to monitor the risk from time to time to be sure that it continues to have a low probability and consequences. Where does she record the risk so that she doesn’t lose track of it?
explanation: You record low probability and impact risks in watchlist. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 423

choices.text: In a trigger
In the Risk Report
In the Risk Management Plan
On a watchlist

text: Andy is a project manager for a software project. The scope of the project was approved by the customer and key stakeholders at the beginning of the project, but whenever the customer validates deliverables, he comes up with new requirements that he would like to add into the product. Andy is working with the customer to find what requirements were missed in the planning stages of the project and how to plan better in the future. What is the best description of his project’s current situation?
explanation: Scope creep means the uncontrolled expansion to product or project scope without adjustments to time, cost, and resources. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 168 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 87

choices.text: Rolling wave planning
Scope creep
Alternatives analysis
Product analysis

text: You are a project manager for a large construction project. The project is to build a new hotel. The project is divided into five phases and it is highly visible in your organization. To ensure formalizing acceptance of the completed project deliverables, you decided to validate scope with the customer to ensure that the project is on track from the customer point of view. When should the Validate Scope process be performed?
explanation: The scope is validated at the end of each phase to ensure that the phase deliverables are accepted by the customer before moving forward to the next phase. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 164

choices.text: At the end of each phase of the project
At the beginning of the project
At the end of the project
During the planning process

text: Peter is a product owner for a software project that is being implemented using agile methodology. During an iteration review, the team demonstrates theA software project that is being implemented using agile methodology. During an iteration review, the team demonstrates the completed product increment during the last iteration. He rejects one of the product features that the development team demonstrated. What should happen next?
explanation: As the feature is rejected, so it means that it does not meet the definition of done or there is a difference between what was done and what was expected. So, it is needed to close this gap by re-writing the related user stories. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: The team should try to convince the product owner to accept the feature.
The related user stories should be added to the next iteration backlog.
The team should re-write the related user stories to address the rejection reason.
The related user stories are returned back to the product backlog for re-prioritization.

text: An automobile manufacturer has started a project to build more fuel-efficient cars using a hybrid development approach. The project consists of five sequential phases and each phase has multiple deliverables. The project manager mainly use predictive life cycle with some agile practices. Which agile practices can the project manager recommend to the team to make certain that the deliverables are completed and delivered as expected?
explanation: The definition of done is a checklist of all the criteria required to be met so that a deliverable can be considered ready for customer use. This approach helps ensure that stakeholders agree at the start of the project that the work is not only completed, but a shared understanding of done and the criteria to accept the work are exactly defined. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 85

choices.text: Retrospective
Iteration planning
Definition of done
Backlog refinement

text: Which of the following is a basic rule for creating a work breakdown structure?
explanation: The WBS is a hierarchical decomposition of the total scope of work. Each descending level of the WBS represents an increasingly detailed definition of the project work. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 161 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 84

choices.text: Each level of a work breakdown structure is a smaller segment of the level above.
It should list the relationships between different activities.
Each level of a work breakdown structure is a larger segment of the level above.
The planned work is contained within the highest level of WBS components.

text: Sam is managing a project to develop a new billing system for an organization. He has finished collecting project requirements when it was discovered that the finance manager requirements were not collected. Which of the following documents is outdated and caused this issue?
explanation: It is clear that the finance manager was not added to the stakeholder register that is why his requirements were missed. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 41 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 12

choices.text: Requirements documentation
Project charter
Stakeholder register
Requirements traceability matrix

text: A large electronics organization has initiated a project to develop a new gaming device. The initial schedule to develop the new device with a set of pre-defined features is 6 months. Another competitor has launched a similar product with the same features. The project team has increased the number of features to stay relevant with the market. This pushes the launch date two more months. This is known as:
explanation: In this situation, the definition of the project goal being delivered or "done" is constantly moving. Project teams track the planned rate of project goal achievement relative to the rate of progress toward completion. The longer the project takes to complete, the further the project goal of "done" is likely to move. This is sometimes referred to as "done drift." Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 85

choices.text: Gold plating
Scope decomposition
Done drift
Scope creep

text: You have been assigned to manage a software project that should be completed within three months. A project charter has been created. You met with the customer, sponsor and key stakeholders to collect requirements and developed a project scope statement. A project management plan has been developed and approved by key stakeholders. You met with the actual user who will use the product of the project to demonstrate how the product of the project will work and discovered that the user's requirements are different from the ones you were initially given and approved by key stakeholders. What should you do?
explanation: You must collect new requirements of the user which will lead to changing parts of the project management plan through change request. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 168 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 83

choices.text: Complete the work as originally planned.
Re-plan the project to include the new requirements.
Try to meet other users to collect other requirements.
Create a change request for the user's requirements.

text: A project team is working on his first project using adaptive approach. The team facilitator is coaching them about using Kanban board and the importance of limiting work in progress (WIP). All of the following are advantages of limiting WIP on agile projects, except:
explanation: Work in progress (WIP) is the term given to work that has been started but has not yet been completed. Excessive levels of WIP are associated with a number of problems like hiding bottlenecks, representing risk in the form of potential rework, and consuming investment capital and delivering no return. It is not related to managing project resources and their utilization. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 66

choices.text: Limiting WIP helps agile teams to avoid the risk of potential rework.
Limiting WIP helps agile teams to easily identify and remove bottlenecks.
Limiting WIP allows agile teams to optimize throughput.
Limiting WIP allows agile teams to properly manage project resources and manage their utilization to work more efficiently.

text: A team member informs the project manager that he has added an extra functionality to the work package assigned to him which was not included in the design. The new functionality did not add any extra cost and he created it during his weekend. The team member believes that it will satisfy the customer and he will appreciate it. What should the project manager do?
explanation: Adding unplanned functionality is referred to as gold plating and it is not recommended. The team should build what was designed only. Domain = Process.

choices.text: Reward the team member for meeting and exceeding customer expectations.
Remove the new functionality and instruct the team member to build only what is included in the design.
Thanks the team member for his effort and invite the customer for a meeting to inform him about the new added functionality.
Submit a change request to add the new functionality to design.

text: An advantage of the burnup chart is that:
explanation: The burnup chart is useful because it can show changes in scope, making the impact of those changes visible. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 63

choices.text: It can show the remaining work to be done.
It can show changes in project costs.
It can show changes in scope.
It can show the individual team members performance.

text: You are managing an industrial project. The project team has successfully produced the first release of the project deliverables. The deliverables are being inspected by the quality control department in the organization. What should be done next?
explanation: Project deliverables are reviewed with the customer to gain formal acceptance of the product through the Validate Scope process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 164

choices.text: Verified deliverables should be reviewed with the customer to gain formal acceptance of the product.
Verified deliverables should be delivered to the customer and begin project closure procedures.
Document lessons learned and begin project closure procedures.
Continue producing the remaining project deliverables.

text: You are the project manager performing intranet project for your company. During planning the project with your team, you divide up all of the work into work packages and create a WBS. For each one of the work packages, you write down details such as initial estimates, assumptions, predecessor and successor work packages. Where do you store all of that information?
explanation: WBS dictionary gives all the details that you know about each work package in the WBS, including estimates and billing information. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 162 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 85

choices.text: Scope Management Plan
WBS
WBS Dictionary
Project Scope Statement

text: Tony is a project manager for a complex software project. The project is very large and is very important to the customer. He has finished the software system, and obtained acceptance from customer, but few days later, the software system was found to give unexpected results. The customer is very angry and he needs a solution for this problem. Which of the following best describes what should he do first?
explanation: Reviewing the customer’s inspection process is not the responsibility of the project manager. He may apologize to the customer later when he knows the root cause of the problem. Doing nothing is against the professional and social responsibility of the project manager. So, the best choice is to review the validate scope process during which the product was accepted. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 164

choices.text: He should do nothing, the customer has accepted the project.
He should apologize to the customer.
He should review the validate scope process.
He should review the customer’s inspection process.

text: You are leading an agile team working on a software project to develop a mobile application. You and the team have completed the last iteration and are going to demonstrate the completed product increment to the stakeholders during the sprint review. What is the most valuable feedback of the product demo?
explanation: "All the required features exist in the increment" means that the objectives are met and product increment is accepted. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: All the required features exist in the increment.
The customer representative wants to thanks the team for their efforts.
The customer may assign future projects to your team.
The marketing manager liked the product increment and wants to show it to the customer.

text: Chris has been assigned to manage a large construction project which involves a large number of stakeholders. Chris has started with the project team to collect project requirements from stakeholders. It seems that many stakeholders have contradicting requirements and some stakeholders have unclear requirements. What should Chris and his team do in this situation?
explanation: Requirements should be collected from all stakeholders. Filling a survey will neither uncover all requirements nor clear conflicts between contradicting requirements. The best option is to hold face-to-face meetings with all stakeholders to understand their requirements and expectations. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 140 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 82

choices.text: To effectively collect the exact needed requirements, the project team needs to collect requirements from key stakeholders only.
To remove the conflict between contradicting requirements, the project team needs to use Delphi technique as a form of expert judgment.
To build consensus regarding the project requirements, the project team needs to hold face-to-face meetings with all stakeholders to understand their requirements and expectations.
To collect requirements from a large number of stakeholders, the project team needs to send a survey template to be filled out by all stakeholders.

text: Brian has just joined a large construction company as a project manager. He has been assigned to manage his first project in the company. Midway through the project, he noticed that the customer is getting frequent change requests implemented by informally approaching the team members. This has resulted in work disruption and discontent among team members. What should be his first priority to remedy the situation?
explanation: Controlling the project scope ensures all requested changes and recommended corrective or preventive actions are processed through the Perform Integrated Change Control process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 168 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 87.

choices.text: Begin creating a detailed project scope statement.
Call for a meeting with the customer and team members to solve the problem.
Modify the project management plan so that all change requests must be approved by you.
Ensure proper project scope control.

text: For which of the following can a work breakdown structure be used?
explanation: WBS doesn't show durations, relationships, or reasons to initiate a project. It is a component of scope baseline which is used as a basis of comparison between actual performance and what was planned. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 161 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 84

choices.text: Showing the relationships between activities
Communicating with the customer
Showing durations for each work package
Showing the reasons to initiate the project

text: Sergio is the sponsor of a large software project. The project includes 1250 stakeholders located in three different countries. He assigned Michael as a project manager for this project. Mario, a business analyst with a good experience, is assigned to this project to conduct business analysis. Who is responsible for ensuring that requirements-related work is accounted for in the project management plan and that requirements-related activities are performed on time and within budget?
explanation: The project manager is responsible for ensuring that requirements-related work is accounted for in the project management plan and that requirements-related activities are performed on time and within budget and deliver value. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 132

choices.text: Sergio
Michael
Mario
Project team members

text: You are a project manager of a seven-month construction project. The project is very important to the customer and your organization. You have held weekly meetings with your project customer and key stakeholders. After six months of work, the project is on schedule and budget, but the customer is not satisfied with the project deliverables. This situation may delay the project completion date by two months. Which of the following is the most important process that could have prevented this situation?
explanation: The question here is asking about the process that could have prevented this situation. If the project scope, product scope and project deliverables were defined in details during the Define Scope process, it would prevent this situation to happen. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 154 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 84

choices.text: Define Scope
Control Risks
Control Schedule
Control Scope

text: Sergio is the sponsor of a large software project. The project includes 1250 stakeholders located in three different countries. He assigned Michael as a project manager for this project. Mario, a business analyst with a good experience, is assigned to this project to conduct business analysis. Who is responsible for requirements related activities in this project?
explanation: If a business analyst is assigned to a project, requirement-related activities are the responsibility of that role. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 132

choices.text: Sergio
Michael
Mario
Project team members

text: The development team of an agile project has not completed any new features during the last iteration. They are going to hold a product demonstration with the customer representative and stakeholders. What should they do?
explanation: Lessons learned and why no new features were completed can be discussed during the retrospective. During product demonstration (iteration review), the team and stakeholders review what was accomplished in the iteration and collaborate on what to do next. The Product Backlog may also be adjusted to meet new opportunities. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide.

choices.text: They should discuss the user stories to be added to the next iteration.
The product demonstration should be cancelled.
They should discuss the root cause of having no new completed features during this iteration.
They should discuss the lessons learned during the last iteration.

text: An agile team has completed 10 story points in the current iteration, although the team has committed to complete 15 story points per iteration. What should the team do?
explanation: The project team should complete the 10 user stories and add the remaining 5 user stories to the product backlog. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 64

choices.text: Add more resources to the current iteration.
Re-estimate the team velocity.
Complete 10 story points and add remaining 5 story points to the product backlog.
Extend the current iteration.

text: Joseph is a project manager for a hardware design project. The project is about to be completed when the customer refused to sign one of the last invoices saying that a user manual for the hardware must be delivered. Joseph is surprised because the user manual shouldn't be completed by his company, this happened most likely because:
explanation: The scope statement should state clearly what is as is not included in project work. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 154

choices.text: The work packages were not decomposed to project activities.
Project exclusions were not clearly identified in the project scope statement.
This requirement is not related to achieving any of the project objectives, so it was removed from the requirements traceability matrix.
This requirement was not included in the requirements management plan.

text: A project is on its third iteration review. One of the stakeholders has raised a concern about the product increment of this iteration. Which of the following is the best course of action?
explanation: It is needed to know the stakeholder's concern in more details. So, arranging a meeting with the stakeholder and the product owner to know his concern in details and then the product owner can add the stakeholder's requirement in the product backlog. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: Add an entry in the issue log and reassess requirements collection process.
Hold a meeting with the team and the product owner to address the stakeholder concern.
Ask the product owner to add the stakeholder concern to the next iteration.
The agile coach should facilitate a meeting with the stakeholder and the product owner to discuss his concern.

text: WBS is a good way that helps you to manage a project effectively. In WBS you should breakdown your work into smaller and more manageable pieces. Which of the following doesn’t describe how far to decompose the project work?
explanation: The lowest level of WBS components, which are called work packages can be done by more than one person. Other choices are all true about work packages. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 158 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 84

choices.text: Until it can’t be logically subdivided further.
Until it can be realistically estimated.
Until it can be done by one person.
Until it has a meaningful conclusion.

text: A new project has been initiated in ABC organization using an adaptive approach. The initial project requirements have been determined in the initial planning stages and prioritized by customer and product owner. What should be done to these requirements over the course of the project?
explanation: Agile project requirements should be revisited and reprioritized by customer and product owner over the course of the project. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 52.

choices.text: The requirements should be kept fixed unless a formal change request is raised and approved.
The requirements should be revisited and reprioritized over the course of the project.
The requirements should be kept unchanged to avoid scope creep.
The requirements should be prioritized by the project team as needed over the course of the project.

text: During the iteration planning meeting, the development team has selected 50 story points to be implemented in the next iteration according to the team's velocity. The product owner has requested from them to add two more story points to the next iteration. What should the development team do?
explanation: During iteration planning, the development team has the final say on the amount of work that can be accomplished in the iteration. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: Reject the product owner request.
Add the two story points to the next iteration.
Replace them by another two story points.
Increase the team velocity to be 52 story points per iteration.

text: The project team has created the first project deliverable. It has been inspected and passed all the quality control tests. The project team needs to have this deliverable accepted by the customer. To obtain the deliverable acceptance, the project team might need all of the following, except:
explanation: The project team can get the deliverable acceptance through the Validate Scope process. The responsibility assignment matrix is not needed in the Validate Scope process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 165

choices.text: The project management plan, containing the scope baseline and the scope management plan.
The verified deliverables completed and checked for correctness by the Control Quality process.
The requirements traceability matrix, linking requirements to the project objectives
The responsibility assignment matrix describing the roles and responsibilities of the project team members

text: Two team members of your project team are discussing together about the correct order of the Monitoring and Controlling processes for Scope Management. One of them said that the Validate Scope process should be performed first, while the other member said that the Control Scope process should be performed first. Which of the following is the correct order of Monitoring and Controlling processes for Scope Management?
explanation: Validate Scope occurs with each deliverable or phase review and Control Scope is an ongoing process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 131

choices.text: First Validate Scope, then Control Scope.
First Control Scope, then Validate Scope.
Both happen simultaneously.
There is not enough information to decide.

text: A project team is working on a software project in an adaptive environment. The team has completed the features of the first iteration and the team demonstrates the working product. The product owner sees the demonstration and rejects some stories. Which of the following is the best course of action?
explanation: As the team completes the features usually in the form of user stories, the team periodically demonstrates the working product. The product owner sees the demonstration and accepts or declines stories. The declined stories should be added to the product backlog and reprioritized accordingly. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: The declined stories should be addressed through backlog grooming and may be incorporated into the next iteration.
The team should work immediately on the declined stories and hold another demonstration.
The product owner should follow the change control process.
The team should refer the product owner to the definition of done.

text: Product scope management involves the requirements that relate to the product of the project. Project scope management involves:
explanation: Project scope is the work performed to deliver a product, service, or result with the specified features and functions. The term “project scope” is sometimes viewed as including product scope. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 131

choices.text: The work the project manager will do to manage the project.
The project management efforts done by the project manager.
All work included in the scope management plan.
The work the project will do to deliver the product scope.

text: Kevin is working on a large software project using adaptive approach. He wants to find the changes in project scope and their impact on the project progress. Which of the following tools is the most appropriate to use?
explanation: The big advantage of using a burnup chart is that it can show changes in scope, making the impact of those changes visible. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 63

choices.text: Burndown chart
Burnup chart
Kanban board
Product backlog

text: Lucas is an agile practitioner leading an agile project. Midway through the project, he and the team discover that they have committed to deliver 50 story points during the current iteration, but actually they will be able to deliver 40 story points only. Which of the following is the best course of action?
explanation: Extending the iteration is not a good solution as it violates the timeboxing concept. Working overtime and modifying the iteration plan are not proactive solutions. The best answer is to complete 40 story points and add the uncompleted stories to the backlog. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 64

choices.text: Extend the current iteration till the team completes the committed story points.
Adjust the iteration plan to have 40 points instead of 50.
Complete 40 story points and add 10 story points to the product backlog.
Work overtime to complete the committed story points during the current iteration.

text: Which of the following is not an example of the definition of "done" in an agile project?
explanation: Creating a shared definition of done is crucial for satisfying our stakeholders’ expectations. Therefore, a shared definition of done is necessary at every level of an agile project (user story – release – product). An objective (quantified) criteria should be used for the definition of done, subjective criteria should not be used. Agile Practice Guide Page 50

choices.text: The product is considered to be (done), when development work is complete, code is documented and refactored.
The release will be considered as (done) when mobile application version is accepted and there are no Priority 1 defects or change requests.
The website is considered to be (done) when the high priority features are complete and beta version gets at least 80% score in user satisfaction survey.
The user story is considered to be (done) when the code development is complete, documented and user acceptance tested.

text: You are a project manager in a large organization. Recently, your organization is facing a financial crisis, and there was a mass layoff for many employees in the organization. Many projects were affected because of this layoff. Your project is one of the affected projects, because almost 30% of the project resources were released due to the layoff. To deal with the limited number of resources, you adjust the start and finish dates to balance between the demand and available supply of resources. What is the technique you used?
explanation: Resource leveling is a technique in which start and finish dates are adjusted based on resource constraints with the goal of balancing the demand for resources with the available supply. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 211

choices.text: Fast Tracking
Crashing
Resource Smoothing
Resource Leveling

text: In the previous iterations, the team velocity was 30, 35, 36, 40 and 39 respectively. There are 260 story points remaining in the product backlog. How many more iterations will be needed to complete the product backlog?
explanation: You first need to calculate the average number of points per iteration (velocity) = (30+35+36+40+39) / 5= 180 / 5 = 36. You then divide the remaining work by the average points per iteration (velocity) = 260 / 36 = 7.2. So 8 iterations are needed. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 61

text: Susan is a project manager for a new software project. This type of projects has not been previously done before by her company and she has never managed a similar project to this one. What is the best method of estimating the time for activities that have not previously been done by her company?
explanation: Parametric and analogous estimating techniques depend on historical information, so they won’t be used because it is the first project for her company, Monte Carlo analysis is not used for estimating activity durations. Three point estimation will be the best choice in this case. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 178

choices.text: Parametric estimating
Monte Carlo analysis
Three-point estimating
Analogous estimating

text: During measuring the project performance against the project management plan, you discover that the project is running behind schedule and the final deliverable will be delayed by one month after the required date by the customer. What should the project manager do?
explanation: Working overtime or requesting to change the project end dates are reactive solutions, even evaluating the impacts of completing the project later is not a good solution. The project manager must be proactive, so evaluating the impacts for crashing or fast tracking is the best solution. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 223 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 58-60

choices.text: Look for options with project team members like adding more resources or performing critical path activities in parallel.
Let the team members work overtime to finish the project on time.
Evaluate the impact of completing the project later than the required date.
Make a change request to extend the project and schedule and submit it to the change control board.

text: A project team are working on an product development project in an industrial environment using Kanban system. They are developing the project schedule. The project activities are relatively similar in size and scope and can be bundled by size and scope. The project manager needs to limit a team’s work in progress in order to balance demand against the team’s delivery throughput. Which scheduling method is the most appropriate to use?
explanation: On-demand scheduling. This approach, typically used in a Kanban system, is based on the theory-of-constraints and pull-based scheduling concepts from lean manufacturing to limit a team’s work in progress in order to balance demand against the team’s delivery throughput. It is often used for projects that evolve the product incrementally in operational or sustainment environments, and where tasks may be made relatively similar in size and scope or can be bundled by size and scope. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 177

choices.text: On-demand scheduling
Iterative scheduling with a backlog
Critical Chain Method
Critical Path Method (CPM)

text: Phillip is leading a large software project using adaptive approach. He has been approached by the project sponsor to know the expected project completion date. Phillip has informed him that the likely completion date is after 6 months, because:
explanation: Each two weeks the team completes 50 story points. The remaining story points are 560, so they need 560/50 = 11.2 iterations = 12 iterations (6 months). Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 61

choices.text: The team average velocity is 50 story points per two-weeks iteration and there are 560 story points remaining.
The team average velocity is 60 story points per two-weeks iteration and there are 600 story points remaining.
The team average velocity is 30 story points per one-week iteration and there are 600 story points remaining.
The team average velocity is 25 story points per one-week iteration and there are 500 story points remaining.

text: You are managing a project for a customer. The customer has stated in the contracted that there will be a 5% of the project budget as a bonus if the project team delivers the project one month earlier than the planned project completion date. Which of the following can you do to exploit this opportunity?
explanation: Crashing is a technique used to shorten the schedule duration for the least incremental cost by adding resources to critical path activities. This will increase the probability of completing the project earlier than planned. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Resource Smoothing
Crashing
Resource Leveling
Outsourcing

text: Bill has just been promoted to a project manager position. It is the first time he manages a project. He is being mentored by Helena, an experienced project manager. Helena advised him that his team members should be involved in developing project schedule and they should approve the final project schedule. Which of the following best describes why he needs the team to approve the final project schedule?
explanation: Team approval to ensure activities can be completed as scheduled. Team approval doesn’t relate to enhancing team buy in or loyalty. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 207

choices.text: To enhance team buy-in and loyalty.
To improve communications.
To ensure activities can be completed as scheduled.
To improve accuracy of estimates.

text: Chris is a project manager for a construction project. He and his team have finished defining project activities and they need to determine the relationships between project activities to create the network diagram. They decided that the first task is "digging work", it must be completed before the second task "pour foundation" begins. The third task "level concrete" cannot begin until "pour foundation" begins. What is the relationship between the "digging work", "pour foundation" and "level concrete"?
explanation: As digging work must finish before pour foundation can start, so the relationship between digging work and pour foundation is Finish to Start FS. As the level concrete can't start until pour foundation starts, so the relationship between pour foundation and level concrete is Start to Start SS. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 190 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Digging work and pour foundation is Finish to Start FS and pour foundation and level concrete is Finish to Start FS.
Digging work and pour foundation is Finish to Start FS and pour foundation and level concrete is Start to Start SS.
Digging work and pour foundation is Finish to Finish FF and pour foundation and level concrete is Start to Start SS.
Digging work and pour foundation is Start to Start SS and pour foundation and level concrete is Finish to Start FS.

text: You have a project with the following activities: Activity A takes 5 days and should happen after the project starts. Activity B takes 8 days and should happen after Activity A. Activity C must happen after the project starts and takes 4 days. Activity D must happen after activities C and takes 6 days. Activity E must take place after activities B and D and takes 6 days. Activity F takes place after activity D and takes 3 days. Activity G takes place after activity E and takes 10 days. Activities F and G are the last activities of the project. Which of the following is true if activity F actually takes 6 days?
explanation: There are three paths are Start-A-B-E-G-End = 29 days, Start-C-D-E-G-End = 26 days, and Start-C-D-F-End = 13 days. If F = 6 days so path Start-C-D-F-End only changes to 16 days. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 210 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 58-60

choices.text: The critical path will be the same.
The project duration increases by 3 days.
The critical path is 32 days.
The critical path changes to start, C, D, F, end.

text: Which of the following relationships is the least used in Precedence Diagramming Method?
explanation: Start to Finish relationships means that the next task can't be completed until the preceding task starts, which is not commonly used. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 190 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Finish to Start
Finish to Finish
Start to Start
Start to Finish

text: Nicole is a project manager for a major software project. The project is very important for the customer. She and her team have finalized the project management plan which resulted in a schedule that is too long. She needs to compress the schedule when she analyzed the network diagram, she found that it can't change. She has extra personnel resources. What is the best thing to do?
explanation: Resource leveling will increase the project duration, Monte Carlo analysis doesn’t relate to increasing or decreasing project durations, fast tracking can’t be applied in this case as she can’t change the network diagram, thus the activities that were originally planned sequentially can’t be changed to be in parallel, crashing the project is the best answer because she has extra available human resources. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 58-60

choices.text: Perform Monte Carlo analysis
Level the resources
Crash the project
Fast track the project

text: You are managing a product development project. Your customer tells you that you need to plan to have an audit team start auditing so that it finishes just before documentation begins. But other than that, she says it can start as late in the project as necessary. What’s the relationship between the auditing activity and the documentation activity?
explanation: The first activity (auditing) should be finished totally before the next activity (documentation) begins, so the relationship is finish-to-start (FS). Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 190 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Start-to-Start (SS)
Start-to-Finish (SF)
Finish-to-Start (FS)
Finish-to-Finish (FF)

text: You have just been promoted to a project manager position. You are assigned to manage your first project. You want to report your project schedule. You asked a more experienced project manager about the best method to report your schedule. He told you there are several methods to report your schedule like network diagrams, milestone chart and Gantt chart. Under which circumstances is it best to use a network diagram rather than a Gantt chart?
explanation: In this question you can read only the last sentence without reading the rest of question. A network diagram is used to show interdependencies between activities. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 218 and PMBOK 7th edition, Pages 58–60

choices.text: Gantt chart is always the best way to report project schedule.
To show interdependencies between activities.
To track progress or to report to the team.
To report to the sponsor.

text: Both teams A and B after the first few iterations have determined their velocity to be 50 story points per iteration. Team A has committed to the planned velocity for the remaining iterations of the project. Team B has constantly exceeded the planned velocity. Which team has higher efficiency?
explanation: The team who commits to the planned velocity has higher efficiency. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: Team A
Team B
Both have the same efficiency
Not enough information

text: An activity has an early start (ES) of day 2, and a late finish (LF) of day 18. The activity duration is 5 days. Which of the following statements is true regarding this activity?
explanation: Activity duration = Early finish – Early start = Late finish – Late start. Activity float = Late finish – Early finish = Late start – Early start. Activity Float = LF – EF = LS – ES. Activity Duration = LF – LS = EF – ES. 5 = EF – 2. EF = 2 + 5 = 7. Activity Float = LF – EF = 18 – 7 = 11. This means that activity has float, so activity is not on the critical path. The project float doesn't equal the activity float. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 210 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 58-60

choices.text: The activity is on the critical path.
The project float is 11 days.
The project will be delayed.
The activity is not on the critical path.

text: The organization's CEO is highly concerned about one of the agile projects being implemented in his organization. He wants to know the progress of the project. What is the best demonstration of progress that the team can come up with?
explanation: The second value of Agile Manifesto states that we value working software over comprehensive documentation. The seventh principle also states that Working software is the primary measure of progress. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 8

choices.text: Burndown Chart
Working product
Information Radiators
Project Status Report

text: During a hardware design project, a critical path activity was delayed because the predecessor activity was completed later than planned. After investigating the cause of the problem, it was found that the team member responsible for executing the predecessor activity was late in completing the activity, because the estimated time for completing the activity was shorter than the actual needed time. This most probably happened because:
explanation: The team member didn't participate in estimation of durations, thus the estimate is not accurate. The inputs for the estimates of duration originate from the person or group on the project team who is most familiar with the nature of the work in the specific activity. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 196 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 55-58

choices.text: The team member was not involved in estimating the activity duration.
The resources assigned to perform the activities were less than the actual needed resources.
The project manager was not involved in estimating the activity duration.
Historical information was not used properly in estimating activity duration.

text: You’re managing a construction project when your customer required to finish the project earlier than planned due to external circumstances. A team member heard that in a situation like this, you can use schedule compression by either crashing or fast-tracking the schedule, but he’s not sure which one to use. What do you tell him?
explanation: Schedule compression will shorten the project time either by crashing which will increase the cost or by fast tracking that will increase project risk because critical path activities that were originally planned sequentially will be implemented in parallel. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Crashing the project adds risk, while fast-tracking adds cost.
When you crash a project, it always shortens the total duration of the project.
Crashing the project adds cost, while fast-tracking adds risk.
When you fast-track a project, it always shortens the total duration of the project.

text: Lisa is managing a construction project. The project is to build a new office building and it is very important to the customer. The project team has just calculated the critical path duration and informed the customer that the project will take one year. The customer informed Lisa that the project duration is too long and the building should be opened with an official ceremony after ten months. What should she do?
explanation: Adding resources to some critical path activities will shorten the project schedule, this practice is known as crashing. Fast tracking the project can't be done if the project risk is high, because fast tracking increases project risk. Escalating the issue to the project sponsor is not a proactive solution. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Fast track the critical path activities if overall project risk is high.
Add resources to some critical path activities to adjust the project end date to meet the imposed date by the customer.
Inform the customer that the critical path is the minimum project duration and it has no flexibility.
Escalate the issue and ask for guidance from the project sponsor.

text: Michael is a project manager for a product development project. He and his team members are holding a weekly project status meeting. A team member asked the project manager that they will need additional resources to perform a critical path activity which has been delayed. The project manager told him that he forgot to do something before adding resources. What might the team member forget to do?
explanation: They should first try to look for options to compress the schedule before asking for additional resources. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Look for options with the customer before meeting with the project manager.
Level the resources.
Remove float in near critical path.
To try to compress the project schedule before asking for additional resources.

text: Mark compares his team velocity which is 40 story points per iteration to another team's velocity in the same organization with the same size working on similar project and found their velocity to be 55 story points per iteration. What should Mark do?
explanation: There is no meaningful comparison of velocity “between” different teams, since such teams may have different approaches to estimation. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: Acquire more resources to his team.
Do nothing.
Bring this issue for discussion in the retrospective.
Discuss the issue in the next standup meeting.

text: You are managing a construction project to build a new school. You are working with your team to develop the network diagram. A team member suggests that the quality of work could be improved if you start the electricity work before starting the plumbing work. But if it leads to increasing the schedule duration, they both can be done in parallel. What type of dependency is he referring to?
explanation: As the two activities can both be performed in parallel, so it is a discretionary dependency. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 191 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 60

choices.text: External dependency
Mandatory dependency
Discretionary dependency
Internal dependency

text: The same project may be assigned to two different teams, Team A has estimated 420 story points and 30 points velocity per two weeks iteration. Team B estimated 280 story points and 20 points velocity per two weeks iteration. Which of the following statements is correct?
explanation: There is no meaningful comparison of velocity “between” different teams, since such teams may have different approaches to estimation. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: Team B has underestimated project scope.
Team A is more efficient than team B.
Team A didn't account for disruptions in their estimate.
None of the above

text: You are a project manager for a new software project to develop a website for a customer. The customer wants the project to be completed in 40 days. The project is going well and the cost performance index CPI = 1.07 and the project is being performed with four team members, the project critical path duration is 38 days with a standard deviation of two days. What is the maximum project float?
explanation: Mean= 38, the project will take 38+/- 2, range 36 to 40. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 210 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 58-60

choices.text: Four days
Zero days
Two days
One day

text: Which of the following is the most beneficial use of the critical path?
explanation: The critical path is the sequence of activities that represents the longest path through a project, so any delay in the activities on the critical path will delay the project. So the activities on the critical path need immediate attention. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 210 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 58-60

choices.text: To know where you have a spike in the use of resources.
To know where there is float on the project.
To know where to assign extra resources.
To know which activities need immediate attention.

text: You are managing a large software project. Crash the project

text: During measuring the project performance against the project management plan, you discover that the project is running behind schedule and the final deliverable will be delayed by one month after the required date by the customer. What should the project manager do?
explanation: Working overtime or requesting to change the project end dates are reactive solutions, even evaluating the impacts of completing the project later is not a good solution. choices.text: Look for options with project team members like adding more resources or performing critical path activities in parallel.

text: Sam is a functional manager in the organization, he called Henry, the project manager three times today requiring to release one of his resources from his project to assign some functional work to him. He called Henry ten times this week for the same purpose. A team member informed Henry that the hardware needed to perform an activity may be delayed. This activity has early start of 5 and late start of 35. The project float is zero. The project is going well and its risk rating is low. The project has SPI of 0.89 and CPI of 1.12. What is the best thing to do?
explanation: It is necessary to identify the most critical problem that needs to be addressed. Is it the impact of phone calls? Of course not, as the project manager spends 90% of their time communicating with others, so meeting with Sam to address the effects of phone calls is not the best solution. Activity crashing that requires the equipment is an incorrect answer because this activity has different early start and late start dates, meaning it has float and is therefore not on the critical path. Looking for opportunities to reduce costs is also not the best choice because the Cost Performance Index (CPI) is greater than 1, indicating the project is under budget. The best choice here is project schedule compression because the Schedule Performance Index (SPI) is less than 1.

choices.text: Crash the activity which needs the hardware.

Look for areas to cut costs.
Crash the project.

text: You are a project manager for a new software project to develop a website for a customer. The customer wants the project to be completed in 40 days. The project is going well and the cost performance index CPI = 1.07 and the project is being performed with four team members, the project critical path duration is 38 days with a standard deviation of two days. What is the maximum project float?

choices.text: Four days
Zero days
Two days
One day

text: An activity has an early start (ES) of day 2, and a late finish (LF) of day 18. The activity duration is 5 days. What is the activity’s float?
explanation: Activity duration = Early finish – Early start = Late finish – Late start. Activity float = Late finish – Early finish = Late start – Early start. Activity Float = LF – EF = LS – ES. Activity Duration = LF – LS = EF – ES. 5 = EF – 2. EF = 2 + 5 = 7. Activity Float = LF – EF = 18 – 7 = 11. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 210

text: Lisa is managing a construction project. The project is to build a new office building and it is very important to the customer. The project team has just calculated the critical path duration and informed the customer that the project will take one year. Fast tracking the project can't be done if the project risk is high, because fast tracking increases project risk. Escalating the issue to the project sponsor is not a proactive solution. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59

choices.text: Fast track the critical path activities if overall project risk is high.

Inform the customer that the critical path is the minimum project duration and it has no flexibility.
Escalate the issue and ask for guidance from the project sponsor.

text: You have just been promoted to a project manager position. You are assigned to manage your first project. You want to report your project schedule. choices.text: Gantt chart is always the best way to report project schedule.

text: You are assigned as a project manager for a risky construction project. You are asked to provide a time estimate for your manager and consider uncertainties in your estimate. Which of the following techniques is most suitable in this situation?

text: During a hardware design project, a critical path activity was delayed because the predecessor activity was completed later than planned.
