text: You are an Agile project manager working on the next feature of your product. The product owner has asked you for an estimate on how long the remainder of the features may take to complete. You look to the team’s velocity chart. Why is this?
explanation: The average velocity, or work completed during each iteration, is the best predictor of future velocity, because previous iterations typically include all tasks and pitfalls that may impact their work.

choices.text: The team’s average velocity across previous iterations is the best predictor of future iterations.
The velocity ensures the team will never work harder than they have to.
The scrum master has the final say over team velocity to ensure the work gets done.
The velocity chart shows how quickly new items are picked up by the team.

text: You are the Agile lead or Scrum Master for your Agile team and planning for the next iteration is about to begin. What will you do first?
explanation: During iteration planning the team should have already broken down features into story cards. Now is the time to reprioritise the cards that can be done based on the business value and the team velocity (what can be completed).

choices.text: Break down the features into user stories.
Write the story card acceptance criteria with the team.
Choose which stories the team will work on in the iteration.
Work with the product owner to prioritise the highest value ones to work on.

text: You are in the middle of a sprint with your Agile team, and moving the project forward with daily stand-up meetings. What is a stand-up meeting?
explanation: The daily stand-up is a short meeting, usually around the Kanban board, where the team say what they have accomplished since yesterday, what they will do today, and anything that is blocking their progress.

choices.text: A project kick-off meeting where stakeholders must stand so everyone is alert.
A project progress meeting where you see how proposed schedule stands up against the actual schedule.
A very quick meeting time-boxed at 15 minutes or less, where the team say what they have accomplished and report any blockers.
A team training meeting focused on continuous improvement of the team.

text: You are the Agile project manager working on a software project, and the development team have identified a major risk for the delivery of a certain feature. That feature is not scheduled until very late in the project. What will you do next?
explanation: Agile risks are prioritised early in development, to reduce and remove those risks. Discovery work is typically done with a spike card, but does not need to be done by the whole team. Allocate a certain amount of time to it, then prioritise the risk early so it is taken care of and you know what you are dealing with.

choices.text: Wait until later in the project, as the problem may be fixed by other features going in.
Ask the developers to find a way to proceed without that feature.
Plan a spike around the risk, identify a solution then prioritise that feature earlier in development.
Remove all other story cards from the current sprint so the team can swarm around the issue and fix it.

text: Your Agile project team is using Scrum to manage the work and deliverables for your project. Which of the below is not one of the Scrum events or artefacts?
explanation: Scrum works with a Product or Feature Backlog, a Sprint Backlog, and delivers in increments or features. Agile teams are typically recommended to work in a co-located space to ensure collaboration, however this is not one of the events or artefacts of Scrum itself.

choices.text: Product Backlog, where the product owner manages a prioritised list of planned product items which evolves from sprint to sprint.
Sprint Backlog, which are the items selected in Sprint Planning for the upcoming sprint.
Increments, or Features, which are all the Product Backlog items completed during a Sprint and a step toward the main vision.
Team Area, which is where the co-located team sits for fast collaboration.

text: Your Agile team has been working with Scrum for some time now and have become quite familiar with its events and ceremonies. You are asked to explain this to other stakeholders within the organisation. What is NOT an example of a Scrum event or ceremony?
explanation: The Change Control Board is a typical part of a predictive or Waterfall project lifecycle, not an Agile or Scrum way of work. It has key stakeholders review any changes to the pre-assigned scope, schedule, and cost, and approve or decline as the project works towards completion.

choices.text: Sprint Planning, where the Scrum team selects the highest priority items.
Daily Scrum, where the team meets to walk through project tasks, often on a Kanban board.
Sprint Review, where the development team gives a demo on the product to the product owner for sign-off or change.
Change Control Board, where all proposed changes are reviewed before adding to the backlog.

text: Scrum is a single-team framework for managing product development. There are certain events, ceremonies and roles and responsibilities within a Scrum team. Which of the below is NOT a role or responsibility in a Scrum team?
explanation: Risk and quality are the responsibility of the whole team in an Agile way of work, and so typically a single person is not responsible for them. The Product Owner ensures the right features are delivered, the development team ensures the code is refactored regularly, the Scrum Master ensures the team process is improved over time, and quality testing ensures features are free of defects.

choices.text: Product Owner, representing the customer and responsible for maximising the value of the product.
Development Team, developing and testing the product, cross functional, self-organising with all the roles needed to deliver the product.
Scrum Master, ensuring the Scrum processes such as stand-ups and retrospectives, coaching the team and removing blockers.
Risk Manager, capturing and reviewing risks and ensuring each one has an assigned owner.

text: Servant leadership is one of the key foundations to an Agile team, where leadership and team participation and openness are encouraged. Which of the below is NOT one of the characteristics of a servant leader?
explanation: Agile and servant leadership work by building towards psychological safety, openness, growth, and ensuring work is free from blockers. It starts with the Scrum Master or coach/leader role, but expands to the whole team.

choices.text: Promoting self-awareness and helping people grow.
Listening to others more than speaking yourself.
Serving those on the team by removing blockers.
Reporting low-performers to ensure the team is streamlined.

text: Your team are about to proceed with the development of a new product for the organisation you work in. Depending on the product, stakeholders, risk appetite, need for value and more, the lifecycle or way of work will change. Which of the below represents an “Incremental” lifecycle approach?
explanation: An incremental project lifecycle or way of work delivers small increments that a customer can use immediately, gain value from, and provide feedback on.

choices.text: It provides unfinished deliverables that the customer can review for feedback.
It provides value in one release after thorough risk, quality, schedule and scope planning.
It provides multiple finished deliverables that the customer can use immediately.
It provides a way for the team to do less with more, by releasing only a small feature.

text: You are working with your Agile team to size the story cards and place them in upcoming iterations. You notice that the points allocated to story cards are getting bigger and bigger with each release. Why might this be happening?
explanation: Agile accommodates for changing scope and should find a regular rhythm of velocity, ruling out A and D. The best answer is technical debt, where code may be rushed to production without being simplified or refactored. With each subsequent release it creates more work to build on and work around disorganised code.

choices.text: The product owner keeps adding scope to the project.
Technical debt is being built on from previous releases.
Team members are not working their full allotted hours.
Team members are working too hard and being burnt out.

text: The project sponsor of your Agile team is quite familiar with Lean and Agile terms and methods. She has asked you for the average Cycle time and average Lead time for the project so far. What will you give her?
explanation: Cycle time is the time for shorter tasks — most often story cards in an Agile environment. Those story cards make up a feature. Lead time measures the time to complete a feature (multiple story cards) from beginning to end.

choices.text: The average time for team leave, and the average time for team attendance.
The average time to complete stand-ups, and the average time to complete retrospectives.
The average time to complete story cards, and the average time to complete features.
The average team downtime, and the average time to complete releases.

text: You are going over the velocity of your Agile team and notice it has increased over the last two iterations. What might be the reason for this?
explanation: Velocity and throughput are similar concepts. Typically velocity is the work completed by the entire team, however if the productivity of one team member increases that will have an effect on the whole team’s velocity.

choices.text: The productivity of one team member has increased.
The team no longer tests each card because they already know it works.
The team estimated the story cards more accurately.
The product owner removed some features from the backlog of work.

text: You are an Agile project manager working with your Agile team and talking through the defects raised in the project so far. To get a more accurate view of effort per card, you ask the quality tester to begin tracking the defect cycle time. What will they report back on?
explanation: Cycle time is the measure of time of a smaller increment, often a story card, from start to finish. Therefore, defect cycle time is the measurement of how long it took to fix a defect from when it was discovered to when it was fixed.

choices.text: How many defects were discovered in that iteration.
How long it took to fix a defect from the time it was found to the time it was fixed.
How many cycles it takes to raise a defect for the developers.
The number of features in the backlog that have experienced defects.

text: You are checking in with the quality tester in your Agile team, and they advise you that there are a number of escaped defects in the most recently completed feature. What are they referring to?
explanation: Defects that make it through testing and into a release are called escaped defects. The cost and risk increase for defects the closer they are to a live environment, making these the most expensive type of defect to fix.

choices.text: A feature that was not completed by the end of the iteration.
A feature that needs to be refactored before the next iteration can begin.
Defects that have made it through testing and quality assurance.
Team members who did not attend the daily stand-up this iteration.

text: Agile approaches emphasise Servant Leadership to empower teams. Servant leadership is the practice of leading through service to the team, understanding and addressing the needs and development of the team members to enable the highest performance possible. Servant leaders approach project work in this order:
explanation: The Servant Leader approaches work starting with the purpose or “why” behind the work, then works with growing and developing people, and finally ensures a solid process for making the work happen.

choices.text: Purpose, People, Process.
People, Systems, Technology.
Information, Reporting, Process.
Plant, People, Machine.

text: You have been part of an Agile team for some time, working on the aspects of servant leadership to improve the results of your team. What is NOT one of those characteristics of a servant leader?
explanation: The servant leader in Agile coaches the team, promotes psychological safety and trust, and encourages the energy and intelligence of others. This approach does not include directive leadership or forcing others to do what you say.

choices.text: Coaching versus controlling.
Promoting safety, respect, and trust.
Promoting the energy and intelligence of others.
Ensuring the team does what you say.

text: The intent of Agile Unified Process (AUP) is to perform more iterative cycles across seven key disciplines and incorporate the associated feedback before formal delivery. Which of the following is NOT a principle that guides the AUP disciplines?
explanation: The principles of Agile Unified Process (AUP) also match those of Agile in general. You may tailor your approach to fit the situation, use some or all of the Agile methods, ensure the team knows what it is doing, and by grooming the backlog the team ensures a focus on the activities that deliver the most value first.

choices.text: Tailoring the approach to fit.
Ensuring the team knows what it is doing.
Collective agreement of scope before delivery.
A focus on high-value activities.

text: The Twelve Clarifying Principles in Agile were designed to give more clarity to the Agile manifesto core values. Which of the following is one of the twelve clarifying principles?
explanation: Agile focuses on early and continuous delivery of value — most often in a software environment, but also in any knowledge work, such as design.

choices.text: Our highest priority is to satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software.
Our highest priority is to ensure executive buy-in by delivering high value items.
Our highest priority is to reduce the impact of change by keeping information to a minimum.
Our highest priority is to plan thoroughly and execute with discipline.

text: You have built an experienced Agile team and have delivered constantly for your organisation. The product owner who has been with you since the beginning has taken another job, and a new team mate joins the team — one with very little experience. Which of the below will you NOT tell them regarding the Product Owner role?
explanation: The product owner role represents the customer or the area gaining the benefit of the value delivered by the Agile team. Because of this, they often have deep knowledge of that area, know what will bring the most value, and are able to prioritise work items efficiently.

choices.text: The Product Owner represents the customer and generates, maintains, and prioritises the product backlog to ensure the highest business value without creating waste.
The Product Owner must have previous experience in Agile to work in the team.
The Product Owner may work with stakeholders, customers, and the teams to define the product direction, and rank the work based on its business value.
Product owners typically have a business background and bring deep subject matter expertise to the decisions.

text: You have delivered half of the features in the backlog for your Agile project. You’ve noticed there is quite a difference in the number of defects over the last three iterations, and you ask the team to investigate both common cause and special cause variation. What will they investigate?
explanation: Variation in Lean is separated into common cause, which is caused by normal operations, and special cause, which is caused by special or new factors.

choices.text: Issues that arose from normal operations, and issues that arose from a unique or new condition.
Issues caused by the common area, and issues caused by the special software.
Issues found in the last release, and issues found in this release.
Issues caused by continuous integration, and issues caused by no integration.

text: You are working in a new Agile team and have reviewed the team velocity over the past three iterations. The maximum number of points completed was 35, and the fewest was 25. What will you do next?
explanation: Agile works on continuous, sustainable delivery. Pushing the team beyond their known limits is not part of Agile practice. Once the team velocity is known it is good practice to set a WIP limit for future iterations so as to not overburden the team. Team members can still pull in new cards to work on if they finish existing work, and at that time you can review the team velocity.

choices.text: Push the team to complete five more than the maximum, and roll over any incomplete cards to the next iteration.
Set 35 as the Work in Progress (WIP) limit, and adjust it during future iterations if the team is able to pull more work than assigned.
Add more people to the team to complete the work, because 35 is not enough.
Reduce the number of features in the product backlog to suit the team velocity.

text: You are the product owner in an Agile team and have a list of features in a backlog that need to be developed. Each feature is assigned a dollar value, representing the return on investment. You would like it to be a risk-adjusted backlog. What will you do next?
explanation: The risk-adjusted backlog is a sprint or release backlog containing risk response tasks for actionable risks. These will be prioritised against the normal features also in the backlog, to ensure risks are addressed early alongside value delivery.

choices.text: Note the risk impacts in dollars against the return in dollars, then reprioritise the backlog.
Adjust the backlog to focus on the largest features first.
Capture known risks for each feature, then place cards to control those risks and prioritise in the backlog.
Create a risk register for the project, then have it signed off by the risk owners.

text: You are the Agile project manager analysing the risk for each feature in your backlog by assigning a probability and an impact score to each risk, then multiplying that to calculate risk severity. How will the Agile team handle items with the highest risk?
explanation: Risk is highest early in the project before items have been completed. By completing the higher risk items first, you are significantly reducing those risks and the threat of unknown issues later on in the project.

choices.text: Change the requirements to remove the risk.
Schedule them later in the project so you can deliver maximum value first.
Schedule them earlier in the project to reduce the risk impact over time.
Place all the high-risk items in a risk iteration where the focus is on reducing risk.

text: The Scrum Master tells you that Agile builds problem solving into its process in a number of ways, using transparency tools and ceremonies. Which of the following is NOT something that is designed to reveal and solve problems?
explanation: Retrospectives, sprint reviews, and daily stand-ups all serve to reveal and solve problems that arise during product delivery. Writing user stories is a useful task, but it is not itself designed for revealing problems.

choices.text: Retrospectives
Writing user stories
Iteration demonstrations and reviews
Raising blockers in the daily stand-up

text: The Whole Team Approach in Agile is an important part of creating the right cross-functional team. The team facilitator is a key member within the whole team. What is NOT correct regarding the team facilitator role?
explanation: The team facilitator role, or Scrum Master / servant leader / project lead, helps grow team members into their own leadership skills and all Agile teams need this on their team. It can be performed by anyone in the team if there is no specific role for it. You do not need a degree in business, but you do need to remove blockers and facilitate problem solving.

choices.text: The Team Facilitator, or servant leader, can be called a project manager, scrum master, project team lead, team coach, or a portfolio manager.
The Team Facilitator must have a degree in business to be sufficiently respected.
All Agile teams need servant leadership on the team.
Team members should build up their own servant leadership skills of facilitation, coaching, and removing blockers.

text: You are rearranging a current Agile team, and you know that Agile teams are cross-functional. What sort of team members will you select as you rearrange the team?
explanation: An Agile team is made up of generalising specialists, or “T-shaped” people, with one deep knowledge area and a wide range of experience in other areas. The whole team is responsible for risk in an Agile team. Shrinking teams is only applicable for mature teams who are performing well and can reduce time and effort.

choices.text: Generalising specialists, with one focus speciality and a wide range of experience in other skills.
Team leaders, with a speciality in leadership so everyone can lead in the Agile team.
Risk specialists, because there is a higher risk in Agile team delivery.
Don’t add team members — you should shrink the team in accordance with the principles.

text: You are helping the organisation set up a new Agile team and making sure they consider the Whole Team approach. What is NOT correct regarding the Whole Team Approach?
explanation: The whole team approach ensures team members ARE multi-skilled, and have at least one deep speciality.

choices.text: The whole-team approach means involving everyone with the knowledge and skills necessary to ensure project success.
The team should be relatively small (successful teams have been observed with as few as three people and as many as nine).
Teams are often 100% dedicated to the delivery, because when switching or multitasking people make more mistakes and experience between 20% and 40% loss of productivity.
Teams should not be multi-skilled as this can distract from the clarity of the role.

text: You are having trouble selecting team members for your new Agile team in a new organisation. What is NOT true about the cross functional team member in the Whole Team Approach?
explanation: Agile teams will use visual management no matter how good they are. Methods like Kanban boards, stand-ups, retrospectives, and burn-down charts are used to improve transparency, coordination, and team effectiveness, regardless of skill level.

choices.text: Cross functional teams consist of team members with all the skills necessary to produce a working product.
Teams do not need to use visual management because they are already good at what they do.
In software development, cross functional teams are comprised of designers, developers, testers, and any other required roles.
Cross Functional team members are critical because they can deliver finished work in the shortest possible time, with higher quality, without external dependencies.

text: There are three main types of role in an Agile team. The Agile team includes representatives for the Product Owner, cross functional team members, and:
explanation: The Team Facilitator, also known as the Scrum Master, Team Coach, Iteration Manager, Project Manager, Servant Leader and many other names. Their role is to help raise and remove blockers for the team, ensure an active flow of work, and problem solve with the team when needed.

choices.text: the Team Creator
the Team Facilitator
the Team Runner
the Team Enabler

text: You are working through the iteration with your Agile team, and are having trouble completing one of the story cards in the sprint. It is dependant on something else being done and the contact is away. What will you do next?
explanation: Problem solving is done with the Agile team. Blockers are raised as soon as possible – at least during a daily stand-up – so the team can swarm around the problem, get help from any experts needed, and move on.

choices.text: Raise a blocker at the next daily stand-up (or before) so the team can swarm around the problem and solve it quickly.
Bring the piece of work in-house so you don’t have to worry anymore.
Ask the product owner to remove that feature for now, you can revisit it later.
Add cost to the budget and find a third party to complete the work.

text: The product owner representing the business on your Agile project is used to a more dictator-style of leadership. You explain that servant leadership is used in Agile to ensure a safe and open environment. Why is this important to product development?
explanation: Psychological safety is one of the most important parts of a high-functioning team, which means having the safety to be vulnerable, admit problems, ask for help and improve. It starts with the leader, and servant leadership contributes to this.

choices.text: So the Agile team lead knows who to blame when things go wrong.
So the team can accurately count the defects and mistakes.
So the team feels free to ask for help, admit to problems or failures and improve.
So the entire team can push work on to each other if they know they have time.

text: Feedback in many different forms is one of the most important parts of successful Agile product delivery. Which of the below is an Agile method for gathering and using feedback to improve?
explanation: Demonstrating the usable increment developed during an iteration to the customer or product owner ensures feedback is gathered more quickly than only at the end of a project. Retrospectives are another method for feedback on the team process.

choices.text: Having a once-weekly working group meeting with project stakeholders.
Conducting sprint reviews or demonstrations that include all stakeholders.
Sending out project reports to project stakeholders to view.
Asking stakeholders for feedback only when development is blocked.

text: You are working on an Agile project where the product business representative is pushing for more and more features to be delivered in each iteration. You know what they are asking is not possible, based on your team’s current velocity. What will you do next?
explanation: An Agile team ultimately serves the customer, and in many cases the customer is the business owner or representative. If they are not also the product owner (or familiar with that way of work), you should show them the team velocity versus how many points are currently allotted, and ask them to prioritise the features they want next. This gives them control over the value delivered, while not overburdening the team.

choices.text: Show them the team velocity chart and the points allotted to cards in the backlog, and ask them to prioritise the features at the next sprint planning.
Add more members to the team so you can get the work they want done.
Ask for another business representative who understands technology better.
Remove some of the features yourself and see if anyone notices.

text: You are working on a traditional waterfall project and the organisation wants to move to an Agile way of work. The functional manager wants to get the benefit of certain Agile tools they have heard about that are used to uncover potential problems before they occur. What will you do next?
explanation: There are many Agile tools to detect and prevent problems, and visual management is one of them. By making the Kanban board visible to all, along with the backlog and velocity chart, everyone can clearly see what the team is up to, if things are going off course, and if there are any blockers. Daily stand-ups, iteration planning, retrospectives, demos, and reviews are all designed to discover problems and solve them early.

choices.text: Write the change into your project management plan and articulate it with project stakeholders.
Set a weekly working group meeting with your project stakeholders to discuss the project.
Iteration planning.
Make the product backlog, iteration Kanban board, and velocity chart all visible in the co-located team area.

text: The Agile manifesto has twelve clarifying principles added to it to help projects and teams understand the Agile values. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle?
explanation: “Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months, with a preference to the shorter timescale,” is one of the twelve Agile clarifying principles.

choices.text: Tailor the project approach to suit the project and the team.
Ensure executive buy-in by reporting frequently to your managers.
Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months, with a preference to the shorter timescale.
Ensure complete planning for your product and release once tested thoroughly.

text: The Agile manifesto has twelve clarifying principles added to it to help projects and teams understand the Agile values. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle?
explanation: As you will know from the various Agile approaches, “Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project” is one of the twelve Agile clarifying principles.

choices.text: Business people should dictate to the development team what to do and how to do it.
Developers can code and release products at a schedule that suits them, for complete autonomy.
Business people and developers mustn’t work together, but they can chat about their work over lunch.
Business people and developers must work together daily throughout the project.

text: The Agile manifesto has twelve clarifying principles added to it to help projects and teams understand the Agile values. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle?
explanation: Agile is about building projects around motivated individuals – the cross functional and “T-shaped” team members – giving them the support needed by removing blockers and ensuring a flow of work.

choices.text: Build projects around a core idea, then brainstorm frequently to get the job done.
Find the right executive support and ensure they tell you the product requirements.
Deliver frequently whether an item has been tested or not, as quality is everyone’s responsibility.
Build projects around motivated individuals. Give them the environment and support they need and trust them to get the job done.

text: The twelve Agile clarifying principles also match up with the best advice for projects, leadership and communication. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle when it comes to project communication?
explanation: An Agile team knows that communicating close, in person, place and time is the most efficient and effective way – often in a co-located team area so other members can pick up information through osmotic communication.

choices.text: The most efficient and effective method of conveying information to and within a development team is face to face conversation.
Communication is always done in writing to ensure you have ongoing proof the communication occurred.
Agile teams ensure downward communication only so the executive in charge directs the product features and work.
When communicating ensure to use various forms such as telephone, writing, face-to-face, and ensure variety.

text: The Agile manifesto has twelve clarifying principles added to it to help projects and teams understand the Agile values. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle?
explanation: In an Agile team, working software is the primary measure of progress.

choices.text: Union attendance is the best measure of team happiness.
Working software is the primary measure of progress.
Finding risks is the only way to avoid failure.
Learning new things keeps a team engaged.

text: You are new to your Agile project, and the team are working through the forming stages. How do you help the team improve as the project progresses?
explanation: Agile uses retrospectives at the end of each iteration with the whole team to ask “What went well?”, “What did not go so well?”, “What did I learn?” and “What still puzzles me?”. The lessons from this session are actioned and built back into future iterations to improve quickly.

choices.text: Ensure the team holds a project post-mortem and captures the lessons learned at the end of the project.
Hold a retrospective with the whole team at the end of each iteration and build those lessons learned into each new iteration.
Ask the product owner to show the team where they can improve to deliver the features they want.
Rotate tasks and roles amongst the team during each new iteration.

text: You are the Agile project manager working through the product requirements for the product owner and executive project sponsor. The project sponsor raises concerns that the development team do not fully understand the requirements. What will you do next?
explanation: Agile uses fast visual mock-ups or prototypes such as storyboards, wireframes, or models, to get a quick understanding of the requirements and consensus from all stakeholders.

choices.text: Show them the project management plan, which will have the scope statement listed in the scope baseline.
Ask the team to create a high-level prototype of the requirements, then discuss and review with all stakeholders.
Show them the project schedule, outlining each feature and their delivery dates.
Hold a retrospective with the team to gather feedback and improve.

text: The Scrum Master on your Agile project has asked you for the total lead time of a particular feature. You add up the cycle time of all the cards that contributed to that feature. What other two factors must you take into consideration when calculating total lead time?
explanation: Lead time is a concept from Lean and the Toyota Production System. Whenever you are calculating cycle time (smaller items such as processes, story cards, or an iteration) or lead time (larger items such as features or the project itself), you must take into consideration both value-added time (that directly contributes to the customer outcome) and non-value-added time (that does not directly contribute to the customer outcome).

choices.text: Time for testing the code and time for merging the code.
Meeting times and lunch times.
Value-added time and non-value added time.
Testing and documenting.

text: When working in an Agile team it is common to use prototypes, demonstrations and reviews, wireframes and storyboards to elicit feedback from the customer or product owner. What is the benefit of using these tools?
explanation: Prototypes, wireframes and storyboards are important ways to gather feedback, and that feedback allows all stakeholders to discuss and agree on the requirements and product features before money is spent on actual development.

choices.text: So the development team don’t have to create the real thing.
So the team can get together and have another meeting.
It allows users to create new forms that will be required for the new system.
It allows the product owner to discuss and agree on requirements with their stakeholders.

text: You are finishing up the first iteration on your Agile project and have set a retrospective meeting for the whole team. One member of the team asks why you have this meeting and if they really need to go. What will you tell them?
explanation: Retrospectives are a set meeting at the end of each sprint that actively ask for feedback with certain questions: What went well, what didn’t go well, what still puzzles me? The actions from these questions are built back into the team in future iterations.

choices.text: It helps the team prioritise product features for the next iteration.
It allows the team to blame others when things go wrong.
It’s an opportunity for the whole team to look at their way of work and improve.
It showcases a part of the product so everyone can see what was delivered.

text: You are in the beginning stages of a new project, where the organisation would like to use an Agile approach to managing the project work. The executive manager asks you how the team will make quality everyone’s responsibility, leverage the various skill sets within the team, and remove reliance on external inputs. What Agile method is she describing?
explanation: The whole team approach aims to bring all necessary people into the project team, ideally in a co-located space. It involves cross-functional team members who specialise in one skill and are capable across a wide range of other skills, ensuring quality is owned by the team and reducing reliance on external inputs.

choices.text: Servant Leadership.
Sprint planning.
The daily stand-up.
The whole team approach.

text: You have been working on an Agile project for some time and have been blocked by the need for expertise in another team. You need to overcome organisational silos. What will you do?
explanation: This is describing the Whole Team Approach, where all the necessary team members and skills are brought into the project team to remove dependencies, reduce handoffs, and overcome organisational silos.

choices.text: Work with the various managers of team members you need and have them dedicate the necessary individuals to the cross-functional team.
Raise a change request for review by the project Change Control Board as the work will be delayed.
Raise an issue in the issue log for review and management by the project team.
Work with the risk team to raise a project risk, assign it to an owner and create controls for those risks.

text: The twelve Agile clarifying principles also match up with the best advice for workflow and getting things done. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle when it comes to project workflow?
explanation: Agile promotes sustainable development, where the team is not overburdened and is able to work at a constant pace indefinitely. Be wary of often switching tasks or pushing for too much work during each iteration — this will burn out individuals and ultimately slow down progress.

choices.text: Agile does not use processes, as it prefers individuals and interactions over processes and tools.
Agile processes engage and support the team by ensuring sponsors, developers and users all get what they want.
Agile processes promote sustainable development. The sponsors, developers, and users should be able to maintain a constant pace indefinitely.
Agile processes help as much work get done as possible. When the team can’t go any further, Agile pushes them to go the extra mile.

text: The twelve Agile clarifying principles also match up with the best advice for quality in a project. Which of the below is a correct Agile clarifying principle when it comes to project quality?
explanation: While some of these answers match up with Agile practices in general, only “Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design enhances quality” is one of the twelve Agile clarifying principles.

choices.text: Continuous flow ensures work is done at a reasonable pace and defects are caught.
Testing is done at all levels, from unit testing to end to end testing.
Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design enhances quality.
Quality is everyone’s responsibility in an Agile team, meaning everyone will test the product.

text: The twelve Agile clarifying principles also match up with the best advice for keeping things simple in a project. Which of the below is a correct Agile clarifying principle?
explanation: The correct answer here is “Simplicity — the art of maximising the amount of work not done — is essential”, which is one of the Agile clarifying principles.

choices.text: Simplicity is only possible when the team first understands how complex the system is.
Simplicity is part of every project, everyone naturally simplifies the work as part of their role.
Simplicity reduces cost in a project, ensuring executives are always simplifying the process and the system.
Simplicity — the art of maximising the amount of work not done — is essential.

text: You are going through a retrospective with your team at the end of the sprint, where the team have raised an issue that is slowing down their work. The Scrum Master guides the team to go through an exercise called the Five Whys. What is the purpose of this?
explanation: The Five Whys is a problem-solving technique from Lean or the Toyota Production System that asks “why” a problem occurred. For each answer, the team asks “why” again, until they get to the real root cause of the issue.

choices.text: To ask who, what, where and when to find the cause of the problem.
To ask why the issue happened, then why for each reason after that, until the cause is found.
To ask why the team is working on each feature, to give the team purpose.
To allocate five whys to each story card to ensure the team knows the reason for working on it.

text: The Scrum Master in the Agile team has asked the team to do a team self-assessment. What is the focus of this assessment?
explanation: The team self-assessment is used to gauge the team members’ performance together, with the results helping to identify what is working well and where improvements can be made. The team then meets to problem solve improvements and to celebrate what is working well.

choices.text: How often the team meets during the week.
How many story cards the team have completed during this iteration.
How much yearly bonus the team should receive.
How the team performs and delivers together.

text: You are working in an Agile team and the business representative would like to get an idea of the risk associated with a particular feature. What will you do next?
explanation: A pre-mortem looks at reasons for failure before they happen, and is a great way to brainstorm risk for a card or feature. Typically, team members write their reasons down then discuss in a round-robin style, as some people may come up with ideas others have not considered.

choices.text: Show the risk management plan from your project management plan to the business rep.
Ask the development team if they like the feature.
Hold a pre-mortem, where each team member writes reasons they think the task or feature might fail so these can be discussed.
Check your gut-feel for the feature, and if it doesn’t feel right look into it more deeply.

text: You are the Agile team leader and are working through a team retrospective when an issue experienced by the team is raised. What will you do next?
explanation: When an issue is raised the best course of action is to get to the root cause of the issue. Of the items presented, fishbone or Ishikawa analysis is the best tool for root cause analysis.

choices.text: Perform fishbone analysis
Perform Kano analysis
Perform Kano analysis
Perform multi-vari chart analysis

text: You have been hired to lead a new project team as an Agile project manager. As you come on board you learn that the organisation uses a hybrid model. What does this mean?
explanation: A hybrid project management lifecycle means using both predictive and adaptive methods. Predictive is your traditional waterfall approach, with pre-planned project plans, scope plans, quality, schedule and risk. Adaptive approaches will add a prioritised backlog of features delivered, a Kanban board to manage the work, iterations and retrospectives.

choices.text: The team is a hybrid of developers, designers and business users to get the best return on investment.
The product you are developing will use both electricity and fuel for power.
A combination of predictive (i.e. a project plan) and adaptive (iterations, backlogs, Kanban) project methods will be used.
A hybrid team environment of physical and software reporting boards will be used.

text: The Agile manifesto has twelve clarifying principles added to it to help projects and teams understand the Agile values. They are also a best practice on improving the team over time. Which of the below is a correct clarifying principle?
explanation: The correct Agile clarifying principle is: “At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behaviour accordingly,” which in practice becomes the team retrospective.

choices.text: The team will meet daily to build a supportive network of workers.
At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behaviour accordingly.
Features are regularly improved through refactoring of the code.
The project sponsor regularly swaps team member roles to keep everyone learning and growing.

text: The Agile manifesto has twelve clarifying principles added to it to help projects and teams understand the Agile values. Which of the below is NOT an Agile clarifying principle?
explanation: Each of these are correct Agile clarifying principles, except answer B, “Ensure delivery timelines are met at all costs.”

choices.text: Our highest priority is to satisfy the customer through early and continuous delivery of valuable software.
Ensure delivery timelines are met at all costs.
Welcome changing requirements, even late in development. Agile processes harness change for the customer’s competitive advantage.
Deliver working software frequently, from a couple of weeks to a couple of months, with a preference to the shorter timescale.

text: You are the product owner in an Agile team, working with the developers to create Story Cards to place in the product backlog. In the three C’s of user story creation, what will you do first?
explanation: The three C’s of User Story Creation include: Creating the card, Conversation with the product owner and developers to explain how the software or design will be used, and Confirming the acceptance criteria and the definition of done.

choices.text: Create the card, which is the physical (or software driven) media describing a user story.
Confirm the acceptance criteria to go into the user story.
Have a conversation with the team to flesh out the requirements and criteria.
Catch defects before they are developed by working with Quality testers before and after.

text: You are working on the product backlog with your Agile project team, and creating user stories to be prioritised. Which of the below is the best answer for what should go into a user story card?
explanation: Agile story cards should have the requirement, its criticality, test details, and clear acceptance criteria.

choices.text: Key risks of the project and the feature being delivered, with their owners and mitigations.
A wireframe of the feature to be developed that developers can work with.
The requirement, its criticality, expected development and test duration, and the acceptance criteria for that story.
The benefit of the feature so key stakeholders are aware of what they will get.

text: You are an Agile project manager and have begun creating user stories with your Agile project team to go into the product backlog. You have created the card, added requirements, criticality and acceptance criteria. What will you do next?
explanation: The three C’s of user story creation are: Card, Conversation and Confirmation. Once the user story card is created, have a conversation with developers and testers to ensure understanding, check for any gaps, and estimate the effort required. Finally, confirm the acceptance criteria. You can then place it in the backlog for prioritisation in an upcoming sprint.

choices.text: Place the card on the Kanban board so the team can clearly see the future work.
Have a conversation with developers about how the software will be used, confirm the acceptance criteria and definition of done.
Prioritise the card in the upcoming sprint backlog to ensure the work gets done.
Advise the project sponsor and risk manager of the feature details to ensure risk is captured.

text: During a critical testing phase of a hybrid project, two senior team members disagree on whether to adapt the test strategy based on new stakeholder feedback. One insists on following the original approved test plan, citing risks to traceability and sign-off, while the other argues the plan should evolve to reflect the latest priorities. The disagreement has created tension in recent standups and is beginning to distract the team. What should the project manager do to effectively address the situation?
explanation:
Meet with the team members individually to understand their perspectives and uncover underlying concerns
CORRECT: This reflects PMI’s recommended approach for interpreting the root cause of conflict before addressing it. By listening to each team member separately, the project manager can identify misalignments, emotional drivers, or misunderstandings and reduce defensiveness before facilitating resolution.

B. Reinforce the need to follow the approved test plan to avoid setting a precedent for informal change
WRONG: While adherence to approved plans is important, this approach suppresses the conflict without exploring the context or source. It may ignore valid concerns and damage psychological safety on the team.
C. Remind the team that responding to change is key in hybrid environments and ask them to adjust the plan
WRONG: Promoting flexibility is aligned with agile principles, but asking the team to adjust the plan without first resolving the conflict or consulting affected parties risks bias and undermines structured decision-making.
D. Bring the issue to the product owner and test lead to determine which testing direction supports business goals
WRONG: While stakeholder alignment is valuable, this bypasses conflict management responsibilities. The project manager should first work to reduce friction internally before involving external decision-makers.

choices.text: Meet with the team members individually to understand their perspectives and uncover underlying concerns
Reinforce the need to follow the approved test plan to avoid setting a precedent for informal change
Remind the team that responding to change is key in hybrid environments and ask them to adjust the plan
Bring the issue to the product owner and test lead to determine which testing direction supports business goals

text: During a major release cycle, a conflict emerges between a developer and a QA lead regarding the ownership of defect triage tasks. The disagreement stems from overlapping responsibilities not clearly defined in the team documentation. The issue has started to impact the speed of decision-making and frustrates other team members during daily syncs. The project manager notices that these disagreements are now affecting delivery timelines. What should the project manager do to resolve the issue effectively?
explanation:
Re-express the defect ownership process in the team charter and request both team members to align on it
CORRECT: This action acknowledges the administrative root of the conflict — unclear responsibilities — and addresses it by formally clarifying expectations. The team charter is the appropriate place to document and realign overlapping roles, especially in hybrid environments. It is a proactive and contextually grounded solution.
B. Reassign one of the resources to a different project to prevent further delivery delays
WRONG: Reassigning a resource avoids addressing the root cause of the conflict and disrupts team cohesion. It is a reactive measure that could be perceived as favoritism or poor leadership.
C. Escalate the ownership clarification to functional managers and request updated roles
WRONG: While functional managers may need to be involved eventually, this bypasses the project manager’s responsibility to manage team dynamics. The issue is within the team's working agreement and can be resolved without external escalation.
D. Reinforce the agile principle of shared ownership and direct the team to self-organize responsibilities
WRONG: Encouraging self-organization is valuable, but when confusion stems from ambiguous documentation, leadership is needed to clarify boundaries. Simply deferring to the team can perpetuate conflict.

choices.text: Re-express the defect ownership process in the team charter and request both team members to align on it
Reassign one of the resources to a different project to prevent further delivery delays
Escalate the ownership clarification to functional managers and request updated roles
Reinforce the agile principle of shared ownership and direct the team to self-organize responsibilities

text: Two project workstream leads are disputing over the use of a specialized technical resource during a critical project phase. Their disagreement has led to missed internal deadlines. The resource in question is following conflicting instructions and is unsure which task to prioritize. What should the project manager do to resolve the issue?
explanation:
Consult the project schedule and dependencies to prioritize work based on impact
CORRECT: This is a context-based administrative action grounded in project artifacts. It enables the project manager to make an objective decision and maintain alignment with critical path priorities, rather than taking sides.

A. Ask the resource to complete both tasks simultaneously to maintain neutrality
WRONG: This approach may appear balanced but ignores the reality of capacity limits and risks overloading the resource, leading to reduced quality or burnout. It also avoids the root of the conflict.
C. Have the team leads resolve the matter independently in their next joint status update
WRONG: This defers resolution and assumes the leads can align without support, despite evidence to the contrary (missed deadlines). It risks further delay and avoids leadership responsibility.
D. Remove the contested resource from both workstreams to reduce tension and reassess allocation later
WRONG: This may temporarily reduce conflict but it sacrifices a valuable resource and does not solve the actual issue. It disrupts progress and may create new gaps.

choices.text: Ask the resource to complete both tasks simultaneously to maintain neutrality
Consult the project schedule and dependencies to prioritize work based on impact
Have the team leads resolve the matter independently in their next joint status update
Remove the contested resource from both workstreams to reduce tension and reassess allocation later

text: Midway through a predictive infrastructure project, a long-time stakeholder begins questioning decisions that were agreed upon earlier in the planning phase. Their comments during meetings are now creating friction with several team members, leading to distractions and reduced engagement. The stakeholder claims they were not fully aware of the impacts of those decisions. What should the project manager do to reduce tension and move forward?
explanation:
Share the original decision documentation and engage the stakeholder in a targeted follow-up conversation
CORRECT: This option addresses both the tension and the root of the misunderstanding. It shows respect for the stakeholder while reinforcing documented agreements — a balanced, constructive approach aligned with PMI's collaborative conflict resolution mindset.

A. Pause the work and reconvene the planning team to re-evaluate the earlier decisions
WRONG: This introduces unnecessary disruption. Unless the decisions are invalid or requirements have changed, revisiting prior agreements due to one stakeholder’s discomfort is inefficient.
C. Address the stakeholder's behavior in the next team meeting to re-establish authority and cohesion
WRONG: Public confrontation may worsen tensions and damage trust. Issues like this should be addressed privately to preserve relationships and avoid defensiveness.
D. Limit the stakeholder’s involvement in ongoing decision reviews to prevent further disruption
WRONG: Excluding stakeholders undermines collaboration and can escalate resistance. Engagement should be managed, not avoided.

choices.text: Pause the work and reconvene the planning team to re-evaluate the earlier decisions
Share the original decision documentation and engage the stakeholder in a targeted follow-up conversation
Address the stakeholder's behavior in the next team meeting to re-establish authority and cohesion
Limit the stakeholder’s involvement in ongoing decision reviews to prevent further disruption

text: During implementation of a new ERP system, a conflict arises between the finance lead and the operations lead regarding data ownership. Both claim authority over the same set of workflows. The project manager checks the RACI chart and finds that accountability for this area is ambiguously shared. What should the project manager do next?
explanation:
Clarify ownership by engaging both leads in a joint working session to redefine responsibilities
CORRECT: This is a proactive step that promotes alignment through collaboration. It addresses the root issue—unclear accountability—and supports conflict resolution by fostering joint decision-making.

A. Assign control to the finance lead since their group typically governs financial data under compliance standards
WRONG: Although finance may often lead compliance-driven initiatives, this assumes a resolution without stakeholder input. It risks creating resistance and misses the opportunity for mutual agreement.
B. Request each lead to submit their justification in writing before scheduling a decision-making session
WRONG: While structured input can be helpful, this creates formality without resolving interpersonal tension or facilitating real dialogue. It may delay action and prolong confusion if used in isolation.
D. Update the RACI chart to reflect a shared model of accountability and monitor for ongoing friction
WRONG: Simply reinforcing shared accountability without resolving the conflict will likely perpetuate the problem. This avoids the difficult conversation needed to establish clarity.

choices.text: Assign control to the finance lead since their group typically governs financial data under compliance standards
Request each lead to submit their justification in writing before scheduling a decision-making session
Clarify ownership by engaging both leads in a joint working session to redefine responsibilities
Update the RACI chart to reflect a shared model of accountability and monitor for ongoing friction

text: A new cross-functional team is struggling with motivation and engagement. The team includes members from multiple business units, and early meetings reveal differences in communication preferences and levels of assertiveness. The project manager wants to foster cohesion and ensure all voices are heard before moving into delivery. What is the best leadership action the project manager can take in this situation?
explanation:
Establish team working agreements and norms to support diverse collaboration styles
CORRECT: This reflects servant leadership and inclusion by co-creating an environment where team members feel respected and heard. It sets a behavioral foundation that enables high performance later.

A. Assign roles based on prior team performance to encourage early momentum
WRONG: This may unintentionally favor dominant voices and reinforce pre-existing silos. Leadership in this phase should emphasize collaboration and equity, not hierarchy or legacy dynamics.
B. Launch the first sprint and evaluate team interactions through retrospectives
WRONG: Waiting for feedback loops to surface issues may delay necessary interventions. Proactive leadership is preferred when early dysfunction is already visible.
C. Create a shared KPI framework to align team members with delivery outcomes
WRONG: Metrics are useful, but they don't address interpersonal dynamics or psychological safety. Leadership must focus first on team trust and inclusion before emphasizing performance.

choices.text: Assign roles based on prior team performance to encourage early momentum
Launch the first sprint and evaluate team interactions through retrospectives
Create a shared KPI framework to align team members with delivery outcomes
Establish team working agreements and norms to support diverse collaboration styles

text: A project manager is leading a high-visibility project with a team composed of senior, self-directed professionals. While the team is delivering on schedule, they appear disengaged and minimally collaborative. The project manager wants to enhance commitment and team synergy without micromanaging. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Encourage the team to co-create a team charter that reflects shared goals and behavioral norms
CORRECT: Co-creating a team charter enables ownership and reinforces intrinsic motivation. It aligns with the principles of servant leadership and collaborative leadership styles, particularly in mature teams that need engagement, not direction.
B. Reinforce deadlines and deliverable accountability during weekly meetings
WRONG: This directive approach may increase pressure but won’t address the underlying disengagement. It reflects transactional management rather than motivational leadership.
C. Assign each member responsibility for a rotating leadership task to increase involvement
WRONG: While well-intended, assigning leadership roles without clear alignment or context may create resistance in experienced professionals who value autonomy.
D. Reduce formal check-ins and allow team members more freedom to self-organize
WRONG: Less structure may further disconnect the team. Disengagement needs to be addressed through re-engagement strategies, not detachment.

choices.text: Encourage the team to co-create a team charter that reflects shared goals and behavioral norms
Reinforce deadlines and deliverable accountability during weekly meetings
Assign each member responsibility for a rotating leadership task to increase involvement
Reduce formal check-ins and allow team members more freedom to self-organize

text: Midway through a hybrid project, the project manager notices that two team members consistently ask for detailed guidance, while others prefer more autonomy and flexible deadlines. The team is diverse in experience and working styles. The project manager wants to lead effectively while maintaining performance across the team. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Adjust leadership approach based on individual team member needs and engagement styles
CORRECT: This reflects situational leadership, where the manager flexes their style to fit the team’s capabilities and preferences. PMI encourages adapting leadership to maximize individual and collective performance.

A. Implement a standardized task review process to balance control and flexibility
WRONG: While consistency can help, a rigid review process may not account for individual work styles. It could stifle experienced contributors and create unnecessary oversight.
C. Escalate the behavior of those needing extra guidance to their functional managers
WRONG: Needing support is not a disciplinary issue. Escalating undermines trust and ignores the leader’s role in enabling the team.
D. Set uniform expectations for independence to reinforce fairness and team maturity
WRONG: Equal treatment is not always effective leadership. Fairness involves meeting people where they are and supporting them based on their needs.

choices.text: Implement a standardized task review process to balance control and flexibility
Adjust leadership approach based on individual team member needs and engagement styles
Escalate the behavior of those needing extra guidance to their functional managers
Set uniform expectations for independence to reinforce fairness and team maturity

text: A project manager observes that enthusiasm has declined within the team after a few high-pressure weeks. Deliverables are being completed, but team members are less engaged during standups and appear indifferent toward the project’s outcomes. The project manager wants to restore energy and purpose across the team. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Reconnect the team to the project’s mission and stakeholder impact
CORRECT: This aligns with motivational leadership by reinforcing purpose and value. Teams often regain energy when they see the real-world outcomes of their work.

A. Offer a team bonus based on on-time milestone completion
WRONG: While incentives may help short-term, they don't address intrinsic motivation. PMI promotes purpose-driven leadership rather than transactional approaches.
B. Rotate roles within the team to refresh their day-to-day responsibilities
WRONG: Changing roles can disrupt continuity and add stress if not driven by team input. This could lower morale rather than improve it if applied arbitrarily.
D. Reduce workload temporarily and cancel non-essential meetings
WRONG: While well-meaning, this addresses symptoms rather than the root issue — a lack of purpose. Teams need meaningful engagement, not just relief from activity.

choices.text: Offer a team bonus based on on-time milestone completion
Rotate roles within the team to refresh their day-to-day responsibilities
Reconnect the team to the project’s mission and stakeholder impact
Reduce workload temporarily and cancel non-essential meetings

text: A project sponsor who initially showed strong support for the initiative has become less responsive to updates and has not attended the last two governance reviews. Meanwhile, a vocal operational stakeholder has started influencing the team’s priorities, pushing for changes outside the project scope. The team is confused about direction and authority. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Assess the influence of both stakeholders and realign communications to re-engage the sponsor and clarify authority
CORRECT: This demonstrates leadership by analyzing stakeholder dynamics and adapting engagement strategies. PMI emphasizes active management of stakeholder influence to guide the team effectively.

A. Reallocate effort to the operational stakeholder’s requests to maintain momentum and buy-in
WRONG: Prioritizing work based on informal influence undermines the project's approved scope and governance. This can lead to misalignment and loss of control.
B. Send a formal reminder to the sponsor highlighting their governance responsibilities
WRONG: While technically accurate, this may come across as confrontational and won't rebuild engagement or clarify the shifting dynamics within the team.
C. Delay non-critical work until the sponsor re-engages and provides updated direction
WRONG: Waiting passively for the sponsor’s re-engagement causes unnecessary delays and ignores the need for proactive stakeholder management.

choices.text: Reallocate effort to the operational stakeholder’s requests to maintain momentum and buy-in
Send a formal reminder to the sponsor highlighting their governance responsibilities
Delay non-critical work until the sponsor re-engages and provides updated direction
Assess the influence of both stakeholders and realign communications to re-engage the sponsor and clarify authority

text: A newly formed project team includes members from different geographic regions, cultural backgrounds, and departments. Early collaboration is strained, with some team members dominating conversations and others withdrawing. The project manager wants to create a more inclusive environment without imposing rigid team rules. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Initiate a discussion on team norms that encourages input from all members and reflects diverse working styles
CORRECT: This aligns with PMI’s focus on inclusion and servant leadership. It empowers the team to co-create a safe, respectful, and collaborative environment that embraces diversity.

A. Conduct a conflict management workshop to surface and resolve interpersonal differences
WRONG: While useful in cases of overt conflict, there is no indication of active disputes here. The issue is more about psychological safety and inclusion than conflict resolution.
C. Assign quiet team members rotating responsibilities to increase visibility and contribution
WRONG: This may feel forced and doesn’t address the underlying cause of disengagement. Inclusion is about fostering comfort and belonging, not just visibility.
D. Schedule one-on-one coaching sessions to provide private feedback and communication tips
WRONG: While well-intentioned, coaching assumes individual deficiencies rather than addressing the systemic team dynamic. It also lacks the transparency needed to build shared norms.

choices.text: Conduct a conflict management workshop to surface and resolve interpersonal differences
Initiate a discussion on team norms that encourages input from all members and reflects diverse working styles
Assign quiet team members rotating responsibilities to increase visibility and contribution
Schedule one-on-one coaching sessions to provide private feedback and communication tips

text: A project manager is assigned to lead a team of junior professionals who are new to project-based work. The team frequently seeks validation before taking action and is hesitant to raise risks. The project manager wants to build the team’s confidence while still ensuring quality and progress. What leadership style should the project manager apply in this scenario?
explanation:
Coaching style that supports development through guidance and encouragement
CORRECT: Coaching is the ideal style when working with less experienced team members. It fosters confidence, supports learning, and builds competence without micromanaging — perfectly aligned with PMI’s servant leadership mindset.

B. Delegative style that empowers the team to make independent decisions
WRONG: Delegation works best with experienced, confident team members. In this case, it may leave the team unsupported and unsure of expectations.
C. Transactional style that reinforces accountability through rewards and penalties
WRONG: This approach may produce compliance but does not encourage learning or engagement. It could worsen hesitation and fear of mistakes.
D. Transformational style that focuses on long-term vision and strategic alignment
WRONG: While inspiring, transformational leadership may be too abstract for a team needing tactical support and hands-on development early in the project.

choices.text: Coaching style that supports development through guidance and encouragement
Delegative style that empowers the team to make independent decisions
Transactional style that reinforces accountability through rewards and penalties
Transformational style that focuses on long-term vision and strategic alignment

text: During a mid-project checkpoint, the project manager reviews performance metrics and finds that a team member consistently completes tasks on time but with recurring quality issues requiring rework. The team member is enthusiastic and well-liked but unaware of the broader performance concerns. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Meet privately with the team member to provide specific, actionable feedback based on observed trends
CORRECT: This is the appropriate first step. It reflects good feedback practice — timely, respectful, and based on data — and supports improvement while preserving trust.

A. Discuss the quality issues with the functional manager to better understand the team member’s strengths and past development
WRONG: While this sounds collaborative, it defers action. The project manager should initiate timely, direct feedback rather than wait for additional input unless the issue persists after intervention.
C. Acknowledge the team member’s enthusiasm publicly to maintain morale and address quality later
WRONG: Delaying feedback risks normalizing low quality. Recognition and correction must be balanced to drive growth.
D. Rotate the team member to a different role where quality standards are less strict
WRONG: This avoids the problem rather than solving it. Redirecting the person doesn't develop their capability or ensure the project meets quality expectations.

choices.text: Discuss the quality issues with the functional manager to better understand the team member’s strengths and past development
Meet privately with the team member to provide specific, actionable feedback based on observed trends
Acknowledge the team member’s enthusiasm publicly to maintain morale and address quality later
Rotate the team member to a different role where quality standards are less strict

text: A team member has consistently exceeded quality targets and proactively shared best practices with peers. The project manager wants to recognize this contribution and encourage continued knowledge sharing without creating perceptions of favoritism. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Schedule a peer-led knowledge sharing session and publicly thank the contributor for leading it
CORRECT: This approach leverages servant leadership by empowering the individual to influence the team, reinforces positive behavior immediately, and encourages others to contribute, all while avoiding favoritism.

A. Announce the team member’s achievements in the project status report to highlight their impact
WRONG: While recognition is important, broadcasting in a report may feel impersonal and could embarrass the team member or create envy among peers.
B. Provide a formal commendation in the next performance review cycle to document their success
WRONG: This is appropriate for long-term reward, but it delays timely recognition. Immediate, contextual acknowledgment is more motivating.
D. Offer the team member a bonus or gift card to reward their extra effort
WRONG: Financial rewards can work but may set a precedent or be seen as transactional. Recognition that builds team capability and visibility is more sustainable.

choices.text: Announce the team member’s achievements in the project status report to highlight their impact
Provide a formal commendation in the next performance review cycle to document their success
Schedule a peer-led knowledge sharing session and publicly thank the contributor for leading it
Offer the team member a bonus or gift card to reward their extra effort

text: A team member who struggled with meeting quality standards has recently shown noticeable improvement after receiving coaching and feedback. However, the project manager wants to ensure the progress is sustainable and not situational. What should the project manager do to verify ongoing performance improvement?
explanation:
Track task quality and consistency over the next sprint while offering continued support
CORRECT: This reflects a responsible approach to verifying improvement — by monitoring performance over time and providing ongoing reinforcement. It aligns with PMI’s emphasis on data-driven evaluation and developmental leadership.

A. Assign the team member additional complex tasks to test their development under pressure
WRONG: This introduces unnecessary stress and can set the team member up to fail. Development should be monitored in real contexts, not artificially escalated ones.
B. Solicit informal feedback from peers about the team member’s behavior and contributions
WRONG: Peer input can be valuable but may be biased or anecdotal. It shouldn't be the sole method to assess performance trends.
C. Acknowledge the improvement publicly and ask the team member to help coach others
WRONG: Recognition is motivating, but assigning a mentoring role too soon may overwhelm the individual and risk regression if their improvement is not yet stable.

choices.text: Assign the team member additional complex tasks to test their development under pressure
Solicit informal feedback from peers about the team member’s behavior and contributions
Acknowledge the improvement publicly and ask the team member to help coach others
Track task quality and consistency over the next sprint while offering continued support

text: During a team retrospective, one member becomes defensive after another highlights delays in their deliverables. The discussion becomes tense, and the project manager notices other team members withdrawing. The manager wants to address performance concerns without harming team trust. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Meet privately with the individual to discuss the concern and explore how to provide feedback constructively in the future
CORRECT: This reflects a thoughtful, emotionally intelligent approach. It allows for performance concerns to be addressed without public confrontation and supports team psychological safety — aligned with PMI’s values on feedback and trust-building.

B. Ask the team to complete an anonymous performance feedback survey to avoid further conflict
WRONG: While anonymity may seem safe, it doesn’t resolve interpersonal tension or build accountability. It can lead to ambiguity and misinterpretation.
C. Remind the team in the next meeting that accountability is part of working in an agile environment
WRONG: While true, this public reminder can feel like passive reprimand and may further disengage or shame the individuals involved.
D. Avoid direct feedback for now and focus on team-building activities to rebuild morale
WRONG: Avoiding the issue may make things worse. Feedback should be timely, and morale is best built by reinforcing clarity and safety, not delay.

choices.text: Meet privately with the individual to discuss the concern and explore how to provide feedback constructively in the future
Ask the team to complete an anonymous performance feedback survey to avoid further conflict
Remind the team in the next meeting that accountability is part of working in an agile environment
Avoid direct feedback for now and focus on team-building activities to rebuild morale

text: The project manager is conducting a performance review at the midpoint of a long-term hybrid project. Most team members are meeting deadlines, but productivity and engagement vary significantly. The project manager wants to ensure the appraisal is fair, data-driven, and aligned with team goals. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
Compare individual performance data against previously established KPIs and project baselines
CORRECT: This is the most objective and fair method to appraise performance. It ensures that all evaluations are based on clear expectations and measurable outcomes, aligned with PMI best practices.

A. Use informal feedback from functional managers to supplement observations and assess contributions
WRONG: While it may provide context, informal feedback alone is subjective and may be biased. It should not be the foundation of performance evaluation.
B. Rely on qualitative self-assessments to understand the team members’ perceptions of their performance
WRONG: Self-assessments offer insight into confidence and perception but lack objectivity. They should be used as a complement to — not a replacement for — measurable data.
D. Conduct a group review session to evaluate performance collectively and avoid singling anyone out
WRONG: Group reviews dilute accountability and make it difficult to assess individual contributions. Performance appraisals must reflect individual metrics.

choices.text: Use informal feedback from functional managers to supplement observations and assess contributions
Rely on qualitative self-assessments to understand the team members’ perceptions of their performance
Compare individual performance data against previously established KPIs and project baselines
Conduct a group review session to evaluate performance collectively and avoid singling anyone out

text: A new agile project team is composed of individuals with complementary skills but limited experience working together. The project manager wants to foster a culture of empowerment early in the project. Which action best supports this goal?
explanation:
Encourage the team to establish their own working agreements and ways of measuring success
CORRECT: This promotes team ownership, clarity, and cohesion. PMI supports empowering teams to define how they work and evaluate their progress.
